      14                 :           0 :             uint256 offset = 32 - _addressBytes.length;
      15                 :           0 :             result = result >> (offset * 8);
      16                 :             :         }
      17                 :             :     }
      18                 :             : 
      19                 :           0 :     function toBytes32(address _address) internal pure returns (bytes32 result) {
      20                 :           0 :         result = bytes32(uint256(uint160(_address)));
      21                 :             :     }
      22                 :             : 
      23                 :           0 :     function toBytes(bytes32 _addressBytes32, uint256 _size) internal pure returns (bytes memory result) {
      24            [ # ]:           0 :         if (_size == 0 || _size > 32) revert AddressCast_InvalidSizeForAddress();
      25                 :           0 :         result = new bytes(_size);
      26                 :             :         unchecked {
      27                 :           0 :             uint256 offset = 256 - _size * 8;
      28                 :             :             assembly {
      29                 :           0 :                 mstore(add(result, 32), shl(offset, _addressBytes32))

      31                 :             :         }
      32                 :             :     }

      44                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/utils/Context.sol
      45                 :             : 
      46                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.0.1) (utils/Context.sol)
      47                 :             : 
      48                 :             : /**
      49                 :             :  * @dev Provides information about the current execution context, including the
      50                 :             :  * sender of the transaction and its data. While these are generally available
      51                 :             :  * via msg.sender and msg.data, they should not be accessed in such a direct
      52                 :             :  * manner, since when dealing with meta-transactions the account sending and
      53                 :             :  * paying for execution may not be the actual sender (as far as an application
      54                 :             :  * is concerned).
      55                 :             :  *
      56                 :             :  * This contract is only required for intermediate, library-like contracts.
      57                 :             :  */
      58                 :             : abstract contract Context {
      59                 :         248 :     function _msgSender() internal view virtual returns (address) {
      60                 :         248 :         return msg.sender;
      61                 :             :     }
      62                 :             :

      64                 :           0 :         return msg.data;
      65                 :             :     }
      66                 :             : 
      67                 :           0 :     function _contextSuffixLength() internal view virtual returns (uint256) {
      68                 :           0 :         return 0;
      69                 :             :     }
      70                 :             : }

      72                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/utils/cryptography/ECDSA.sol
      73                 :             : 
      74                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (utils/cryptography/ECDSA.sol)
      75                 :             : 
      76                 :             : /**
      77                 :             :  * @dev Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) operations.
      78                 :             :  *
      79                 :             :  * These functions can be used to verify that a message was signed by the holder
      80                 :             :  * of the private keys of a given address.
      81                 :             :  */
      82                 :             : library ECDSA {
      83                 :             :     enum RecoverError {
      84                 :             :         NoError,
      85                 :             :         InvalidSignature,
      86                 :             :         InvalidSignatureLength,
      87                 :             :         InvalidSignatureS
      88                 :             :     }
      89                 :             : 
      90                 :             :     /**
      91                 :             :      * @dev The signature derives the `address(0)`.
      92                 :             :      */
      93                 :             :     error ECDSAInvalidSignature();
      94                 :             : 
      95                 :             :     /**
      96                 :             :      * @dev The signature has an invalid length.
      97                 :             :      */
      98                 :             :     error ECDSAInvalidSignatureLength(uint256 length);
      99                 :             : 
     100                 :             :     /**
     101                 :             :      * @dev The signature has an S value that is in the upper half order.
     102                 :             :      */
     103                 :             :     error ECDSAInvalidSignatureS(bytes32 s);
     104                 :             : 
     105                 :             :     /**
     106                 :             :      * @dev Returns the address that signed a hashed message (`hash`) with `signature` or an error. This will not
     107                 :             :      * return address(0) without also returning an error description. Errors are documented using an enum (error type)
     108                 :             :      * and a bytes32 providing additional information about the error.
     109                 :             :      *
     110                 :             :      * If no error is returned, then the address can be used for verification purposes.
     111                 :             :      *
     112                 :             :      * The `ecrecover` EVM precompile allows for malleable (non-unique) signatures:
     113                 :             :      * this function rejects them by requiring the `s` value to be in the lower
     114                 :             :      * half order, and the `v` value to be either 27 or 28.
     115                 :             :      *
     116                 :             :      * IMPORTANT: `hash` _must_ be the result of a hash operation for the
     117                 :             :      * verification to be secure: it is possible to craft signatures that
     118                 :             :      * recover to arbitrary addresses for non-hashed data. A safe way to ensure
     119                 :             :      * this is by receiving a hash of the original message (which may otherwise
     120                 :             :      * be too long), and then calling {MessageHashUtils-toEthSignedMessageHash} on it.
     121                 :             :      *
     122                 :             :      * Documentation for signature generation:
     123                 :             :      * - with https://web3js.readthedocs.io/en/v1.3.4/web3-eth-accounts.html#sign[Web3.js]
     124                 :             :      * - with https://docs.ethers.io/v5/api/signer/#Signer-signMessage[ethers]
     125                 :             :      */
     126                 :           0 :     function tryRecover(
     127                 :             :         bytes32 hash,
     128                 :             :         bytes memory signature
     129                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (address recovered, RecoverError err, bytes32 errArg) {
     130         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (signature.length == 65) {
     131                 :           0 :             bytes32 r;
     132                 :           0 :             bytes32 s;
     133                 :           0 :             uint8 v;
     134                 :             :             // ecrecover takes the signature parameters, and the only way to get them
     135                 :             :             // currently is to use assembly.
     136                 :             :             assembly ("memory-safe") {
     137                 :           0 :                 r := mload(add(signature, 0x20))
     138                 :           0 :                 s := mload(add(signature, 0x40))
     139                 :           0 :                 v := byte(0, mload(add(signature, 0x60)))
     140                 :             :             }
     141                 :           0 :             return tryRecover(hash, v, r, s);
     142                 :             :         } else {
     143                 :           0 :             return (address(0), RecoverError.InvalidSignatureLength, bytes32(signature.length));
     144                 :             :         }
     145                 :             :     }
     146                 :             : 
     147                 :             :     /**
     148                 :             :      * @dev Returns the address that signed a hashed message (`hash`) with
     149                 :             :      * `signature`. This address can then be used for verification purposes.
     150                 :             :      *
     151                 :             :      * The `ecrecover` EVM precompile allows for malleable (non-unique) signatures:
     152                 :             :      * this function rejects them by requiring the `s` value to be in the lower
     153                 :             :      * half order, and the `v` value to be either 27 or 28.
     154                 :             :      *
     155                 :             :      * IMPORTANT: `hash` _must_ be the result of a hash operation for the
     156                 :             :      * verification to be secure: it is possible to craft signatures that
     157                 :             :      * recover to arbitrary addresses for non-hashed data. A safe way to ensure
     158                 :             :      * this is by receiving a hash of the original message (which may otherwise
     159                 :             :      * be too long), and then calling {MessageHashUtils-toEthSignedMessageHash} on it.
     160                 :             :      */
     161                 :           0 :     function recover(bytes32 hash, bytes memory signature) internal pure returns (address) {
     162                 :           0 :         (address recovered, RecoverError error, bytes32 errorArg) = tryRecover(hash, signature);
     163                 :           0 :         _throwError(error, errorArg);
     164                 :           0 :         return recovered;
     165                 :             :     }
     166                 :             : 
     167                 :             :     /**
     168                 :             :      * @dev Overload of {ECDSA-tryRecover} that receives the `r` and `vs` short-signature fields separately.
     169                 :             :      *
     170                 :             :      * See https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2098[ERC-2098 short signatures]
     171                 :             :      */
     172                 :           0 :     function tryRecover(
     173                 :             :         bytes32 hash,
     174                 :             :         bytes32 r,
     175                 :             :         bytes32 vs
     176                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (address recovered, RecoverError err, bytes32 errArg) {
     177                 :             :         unchecked {
     178                 :           0 :             bytes32 s = vs & bytes32(0x7fffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff);
     179                 :             :             // We do not check for an overflow here since the shift operation results in 0 or 1.
     180                 :           0 :             uint8 v = uint8((uint256(vs) >> 255) + 27);
     181                 :           0 :             return tryRecover(hash, v, r, s);
     182                 :             :         }
     183                 :             :     }
     184                 :             : 
     185                 :             :     /**
     186                 :             :      * @dev Overload of {ECDSA-recover} that receives the `r and `vs` short-signature fields separately.
     187                 :             :      */
     188                 :           0 :     function recover(bytes32 hash, bytes32 r, bytes32 vs) internal pure returns (address) {
     189                 :           0 :         (address recovered, RecoverError error, bytes32 errorArg) = tryRecover(hash, r, vs);
     190                 :           0 :         _throwError(error, errorArg);
     191                 :           0 :         return recovered;
     192                 :             :     }
     193                 :             : 
     194                 :             :     /**
     195                 :             :      * @dev Overload of {ECDSA-tryRecover} that receives the `v`,
     196                 :             :      * `r` and `s` signature fields separately.
     197                 :             :      */
     198                 :           0 :     function tryRecover(
     199                 :             :         bytes32 hash,
     200                 :             :         uint8 v,
     201                 :             :         bytes32 r,
     202                 :             :         bytes32 s
     203                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (address recovered, RecoverError err, bytes32 errArg) {
     204                 :             :         // EIP-2 still allows signature malleability for ecrecover(). Remove this possibility and make the signature
     205                 :             :         // unique. Appendix F in the Ethereum Yellow paper (https://ethereum.github.io/yellowpaper/paper.pdf), defines
     206                 :             :         // the valid range for s in (301): 0 < s < secp256k1n ÷ 2 + 1, and for v in (302): v ∈ {27, 28}. Most
     207                 :             :         // signatures from current libraries generate a unique signature with an s-value in the lower half order.
     208                 :             :         //
     209                 :             :         // If your library generates malleable signatures, such as s-values in the upper range, calculate a new s-value
     210                 :             :         // with 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFEBAAEDCE6AF48A03BBFD25E8CD0364141 - s1 and flip v from 27 to 28 or
     211                 :             :         // vice versa. If your library also generates signatures with 0/1 for v instead 27/28, add 27 to v to accept
     212                 :             :         // these malleable signatures as well.
     213            [ # ]:           0 :         if (uint256(s) > 0x7FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF5D576E7357A4501DDFE92F46681B20A0) {
     214                 :           0 :             return (address(0), RecoverError.InvalidSignatureS, s);
     215                 :             :         }
     216                 :             : 
     217                 :             :         // If the signature is valid (and not malleable), return the signer address
     218                 :           0 :         address signer = ecrecover(hash, v, r, s);
     219            [ # ]:           0 :         if (signer == address(0)) {
     220                 :           0 :             return (address(0), RecoverError.InvalidSignature, bytes32(0));
     221                 :             :         }
     222                 :             : 
     223                 :           0 :         return (signer, RecoverError.NoError, bytes32(0));
     224                 :             :     }
     225                 :             : 
     226                 :             :     /**
     227                 :             :      * @dev Overload of {ECDSA-recover} that receives the `v`,
     228                 :             :      * `r` and `s` signature fields separately.
     229                 :             :      */
     230                 :           0 :     function recover(bytes32 hash, uint8 v, bytes32 r, bytes32 s) internal pure returns (address) {
     231                 :           0 :         (address recovered, RecoverError error, bytes32 errorArg) = tryRecover(hash, v, r, s);
     232                 :           0 :         _throwError(error, errorArg);
     233                 :           0 :         return recovered;
     234                 :             :     }
     235                 :             : 
     236                 :             :     /**
     237                 :             :      * @dev Optionally reverts with the corresponding custom error according to the `error` argument provided.
     238                 :             :      */
     239                 :           0 :     function _throwError(RecoverError error, bytes32 errorArg) private pure {
     240         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (error == RecoverError.NoError) {
     241                 :           0 :             return; // no error: do nothing
     242         [ #  # ]:           0 :         } else if (error == RecoverError.InvalidSignature) {
     243                 :           0 :             revert ECDSAInvalidSignature();
     244         [ #  # ]:           0 :         } else if (error == RecoverError.InvalidSignatureLength) {
     245                 :           0 :             revert ECDSAInvalidSignatureLength(uint256(errorArg));
     246            [ # ]:           0 :         } else if (error == RecoverError.InvalidSignatureS) {
     247                 :           0 :             revert ECDSAInvalidSignatureS(errorArg);
     248                 :             :         }
     249                 :             :     }
     250                 :             : }
     251                 :             : 
     252                 :             : // contracts/libraries/FixedPointMathLib.sol
     253                 :             : 
     254                 :             : /// @notice Arithmetic library with operations for fixed-point numbers.
     255                 :             : /// @author Solmate (https://github.com/transmissions11/solmate/blob/main/src/utils/FixedPointMathLib.sol)
     256                 :             : /// @author Inspired by USM (https://github.com/usmfum/USM/blob/master/contracts/WadMath.sol)
     257                 :             : library FixedPointMathLib {
     258                 :             :     /*//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
     259                 :             :                     SIMPLIFIED FIXED POINT OPERATIONS
     260                 :             :     //////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////*/
     261                 :             : 
     262                 :             :     uint256 internal constant MAX_UINT256 = 2**256 - 1;
     263                 :             : 
     264                 :             :     uint256 internal constant WAD = 1e18; // The scalar of ETH and most ERC20s.
     265                 :             : 
     266                 :           0 :     function mulWadDown(uint256 x, uint256 y) internal pure returns (uint256) {
     267                 :           0 :         return mulDivDown(x, y, WAD); // Equivalent to (x * y) / WAD rounded down.
     268                 :             :     }
     269                 :             : 
     270                 :           0 :     function mulWadUp(uint256 x, uint256 y) internal pure returns (uint256) {
     271                 :           0 :         return mulDivUp(x, y, WAD); // Equivalent to (x * y) / WAD rounded up.
     272                 :             :     }
     273                 :             : 
     274                 :           0 :     function divWadDown(uint256 x, uint256 y) internal pure returns (uint256) {
     275                 :           0 :         return mulDivDown(x, WAD, y); // Equivalent to (x * WAD) / y rounded down.
     276                 :             :     }
     277                 :             : 
     278                 :           0 :     function divWadUp(uint256 x, uint256 y) internal pure returns (uint256) {
     279                 :           0 :         return mulDivUp(x, WAD, y); // Equivalent to (x * WAD) / y rounded up.
     280                 :             :     }
     281                 :             : 
     282                 :             :     /*//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
     283                 :             :                     LOW LEVEL FIXED POINT OPERATIONS
     284                 :             :     //////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////*/
     285                 :             : 
     286                 :           0 :     function mulDivDown(
     287                 :             :         uint256 x,
     288                 :             :         uint256 y,
     289                 :             :         uint256 denominator
     290                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (uint256 z) {
     291                 :             :         /// @solidity memory-safe-assembly
     292                 :             :         assembly {
     293                 :             :             // Equivalent to require(denominator != 0 && (y == 0 || x <= type(uint256).max / y))
     294            [ # ]:           0 :             if iszero(mul(denominator, iszero(mul(y, gt(x, div(MAX_UINT256, y)))))) {
     295                 :           0 :                 revert(0, 0)
     296                 :             :             }
     297                 :             : 
     298                 :             :             // Divide x * y by the denominator.
     299                 :           0 :             z := div(mul(x, y), denominator)
     300                 :             :         }
     301                 :             :     }
     302                 :             : 
     303                 :           0 :     function mulDivUp(
     304                 :             :         uint256 x,
     305                 :             :         uint256 y,
     306                 :             :         uint256 denominator
     307                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (uint256 z) {
     308                 :             :         /// @solidity memory-safe-assembly
     309                 :             :         assembly {
     310                 :             :             // Equivalent to require(denominator != 0 && (y == 0 || x <= type(uint256).max / y))
     311            [ # ]:           0 :             if iszero(mul(denominator, iszero(mul(y, gt(x, div(MAX_UINT256, y)))))) {
     312                 :           0 :                 revert(0, 0)
     313                 :             :             }
     314                 :             : 
     315                 :             :             // If x * y modulo the denominator is strictly greater than 0,
     316                 :             :             // 1 is added to round up the division of x * y by the denominator.
     317                 :           0 :             z := add(gt(mod(mul(x, y), denominator), 0), div(mul(x, y), denominator))
     318                 :             :         }
     319                 :             :     }
     320                 :             : 
     321                 :           0 :     function rpow(
     322                 :             :         uint256 x,
     323                 :             :         uint256 n,
     324                 :             :         uint256 scalar
     325                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (uint256 z) {
     326                 :             :         /// @solidity memory-safe-assembly
     327                 :             :         assembly {
     328                 :             :             switch x
     329                 :           0 :             case 0 {
     330                 :             :                 switch n
     331                 :           0 :                 case 0 {
     332                 :             :                     // 0 ** 0 = 1
     333                 :           0 :                     z := scalar
     334                 :             :                 }
     335                 :           0 :                 default {
     336                 :             :                     // 0 ** n = 0
     337                 :           0 :                     z := 0
     338                 :             :                 }
     339                 :             :             }
     340                 :           0 :             default {
     341                 :             :                 switch mod(n, 2)
     342                 :           0 :                 case 0 {
     343                 :             :                     // If n is even, store scalar in z for now.
     344                 :           0 :                     z := scalar
     345                 :             :                 }
     346                 :           0 :                 default {
     347                 :             :                     // If n is odd, store x in z for now.
     348                 :           0 :                     z := x
     349                 :             :                 }
     350                 :             : 
     351                 :             :                 // Shifting right by 1 is like dividing by 2.
     352                 :           0 :                 let half := shr(1, scalar)
     353                 :             : 
     354                 :             :                 for {
     355                 :             :                     // Shift n right by 1 before looping to halve it.
     356                 :           0 :                     n := shr(1, n)
     357                 :             :                 } n {
     358                 :             :                     // Shift n right by 1 each iteration to halve it.
     359                 :           0 :                     n := shr(1, n)
     360                 :           0 :                 } {
     361                 :             :                     // Revert immediately if x ** 2 would overflow.
     362                 :             :                     // Equivalent to iszero(eq(div(xx, x), x)) here.
     363            [ # ]:           0 :                     if shr(128, x) {
     364                 :           0 :                         revert(0, 0)
     365                 :             :                     }
     366                 :             : 
     367                 :             :                     // Store x squared.
     368                 :           0 :                     let xx := mul(x, x)
     369                 :             : 
     370                 :             :                     // Round to the nearest number.
     371                 :           0 :                     let xxRound := add(xx, half)
     372                 :             : 
     373                 :             :                     // Revert if xx + half overflowed.
     374            [ # ]:           0 :                     if lt(xxRound, xx) {
     375                 :           0 :                         revert(0, 0)
     376                 :             :                     }
     377                 :             : 
     378                 :             :                     // Set x to scaled xxRound.
     379                 :           0 :                     x := div(xxRound, scalar)
     380                 :             : 
     381                 :             :                     // If n is even:
     382            [ # ]:           0 :                     if mod(n, 2) {
     383                 :             :                         // Compute z * x.
     384                 :           0 :                         let zx := mul(z, x)
     385                 :             : 
     386                 :             :                         // If z * x overflowed:
     387            [ # ]:           0 :                         if iszero(eq(div(zx, x), z)) {
     388                 :             :                             // Revert if x is non-zero.
     389            [ # ]:           0 :                             if iszero(iszero(x)) {
     390                 :           0 :                                 revert(0, 0)
     391                 :             :                             }
     392                 :             :                         }
     393                 :             : 
     394                 :             :                         // Round to the nearest number.
     395                 :           0 :                         let zxRound := add(zx, half)
     396                 :             : 
     397                 :             :                         // Revert if zx + half overflowed.
     398            [ # ]:           0 :                         if lt(zxRound, zx) {
     399                 :           0 :                             revert(0, 0)
     400                 :             :                         }
     401                 :             : 
     402                 :             :                         // Return properly scaled zxRound.
     403                 :           0 :                         z := div(zxRound, scalar)
     404                 :             :                     }
     405                 :             :                 }
     406                 :             :             }
     407                 :             :         }
     408                 :             :     }
     409                 :             : 
     410                 :             :     /*//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
     411                 :             :                         GENERAL NUMBER UTILITIES
     412                 :             :     //////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////*/
     413                 :             : 
     414                 :           0 :     function sqrt(uint256 x) internal pure returns (uint256 z) {
     415                 :             :         /// @solidity memory-safe-assembly
     416                 :             :         assembly {
     417                 :           0 :             let y := x // We start y at x, which will help us make our initial estimate.
     418                 :             : 
     419                 :           0 :             z := 181 // The "correct" value is 1, but this saves a multiplication later.
     420                 :             : 
     421                 :             :             // This segment is to get a reasonable initial estimate for the Babylonian method. With a bad
     422                 :             :             // start, the correct # of bits increases ~linearly each iteration instead of ~quadratically.
     423                 :             : 
     424                 :             :             // We check y >= 2^(k + 8) but shift right by k bits
     425                 :             :             // each branch to ensure that if x >= 256, then y >= 256.
     426            [ # ]:           0 :             if iszero(lt(y, 0x10000000000000000000000000000000000)) {
     427                 :           0 :                 y := shr(128, y)
     428                 :           0 :                 z := shl(64, z)
     429                 :             :             }
     430            [ # ]:           0 :             if iszero(lt(y, 0x1000000000000000000)) {
     431                 :           0 :                 y := shr(64, y)
     432                 :           0 :                 z := shl(32, z)
     433                 :             :             }
     434            [ # ]:           0 :             if iszero(lt(y, 0x10000000000)) {
     435                 :           0 :                 y := shr(32, y)
     436                 :           0 :                 z := shl(16, z)
     437                 :             :             }
     438            [ # ]:           0 :             if iszero(lt(y, 0x1000000)) {
     439                 :           0 :                 y := shr(16, y)
     440                 :           0 :                 z := shl(8, z)
     441                 :             :             }
     442                 :             : 
     443                 :             :             // Goal was to get z*z*y within a small factor of x. More iterations could
     444                 :             :             // get y in a tighter range. Currently, we will have y in [256, 256*2^16).
     445                 :             :             // We ensured y >= 256 so that the relative difference between y and y+1 is small.
     446                 :             :             // That's not possible if x < 256 but we can just verify those cases exhaustively.
     447                 :             : 
     448                 :             :             // Now, z*z*y <= x < z*z*(y+1), and y <= 2^(16+8), and either y >= 256, or x < 256.
     449                 :             :             // Correctness can be checked exhaustively for x < 256, so we assume y >= 256.
     450                 :             :             // Then z*sqrt(y) is within sqrt(257)/sqrt(256) of sqrt(x), or about 20bps.
     451                 :             : 
     452                 :             :             // For s in the range [1/256, 256], the estimate f(s) = (181/1024) * (s+1) is in the range
     453                 :             :             // (1/2.84 * sqrt(s), 2.84 * sqrt(s)), with largest error when s = 1 and when s = 256 or 1/256.
     454                 :             : 
     455                 :             :             // Since y is in [256, 256*2^16), let a = y/65536, so that a is in [1/256, 256). Then we can estimate
     456                 :             :             // sqrt(y) using sqrt(65536) * 181/1024 * (a + 1) = 181/4 * (y + 65536)/65536 = 181 * (y + 65536)/2^18.
     457                 :             : 
     458                 :             :             // There is no overflow risk here since y < 2^136 after the first branch above.
     459                 :           0 :             z := shr(18, mul(z, add(y, 65536))) // A mul() is saved from starting z at 181.
     460                 :             : 
     461                 :             :             // Given the worst case multiplicative error of 2.84 above, 7 iterations should be enough.
     462                 :           0 :             z := shr(1, add(z, div(x, z)))
     463                 :           0 :             z := shr(1, add(z, div(x, z)))
     464                 :           0 :             z := shr(1, add(z, div(x, z)))
     465                 :           0 :             z := shr(1, add(z, div(x, z)))
     466                 :           0 :             z := shr(1, add(z, div(x, z)))
     467                 :           0 :             z := shr(1, add(z, div(x, z)))
     468                 :           0 :             z := shr(1, add(z, div(x, z)))
     469                 :             : 
     470                 :             :             // If x+1 is a perfect square, the Babylonian method cycles between
     471                 :             :             // floor(sqrt(x)) and ceil(sqrt(x)). This statement ensures we return floor.
     472                 :             :             // See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_square_root#Using_only_integer_division
     473                 :             :             // Since the ceil is rare, we save gas on the assignment and repeat division in the rare case.
     474                 :             :             // If you don't care whether the floor or ceil square root is returned, you can remove this statement.
     475                 :           0 :             z := sub(z, lt(div(x, z), z))
     476                 :             :         }
     477                 :             :     }
     478                 :             : 
     479                 :           0 :     function unsafeMod(uint256 x, uint256 y) internal pure returns (uint256 z) {
     480                 :             :         /// @solidity memory-safe-assembly
     481                 :             :         assembly {
     482                 :             :             // Mod x by y. Note this will return
     483                 :             :             // 0 instead of reverting if y is zero.
     484                 :           0 :             z := mod(x, y)
     485                 :             :         }
     486                 :             :     }
     487                 :             : 
     488                 :           0 :     function unsafeDiv(uint256 x, uint256 y) internal pure returns (uint256 r) {
     489                 :             :         /// @solidity memory-safe-assembly
     490                 :             :         assembly {
     491                 :             :             // Divide x by y. Note this will return
     492                 :             :             // 0 instead of reverting if y is zero.
     493                 :           0 :             r := div(x, y)
     494                 :             :         }
     495                 :             :     }
     496                 :             : 
     497                 :           0 :     function unsafeDivUp(uint256 x, uint256 y) internal pure returns (uint256 z) {
     498                 :             :         /// @solidity memory-safe-assembly
     499                 :             :         assembly {
     500                 :             :             // Add 1 to x * y if x % y > 0. Note this will
     501                 :             :             // return 0 instead of reverting if y is zero.
     502                 :           0 :             z := add(gt(mod(x, y), 0), div(x, y))
     503                 :             :         }
     504                 :             :     }
     505                 :             : }
     506                 :             : 
     507                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/utils/cryptography/Hashes.sol
     508                 :             : 
     509                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (utils/cryptography/Hashes.sol)
     510                 :             : 
     511                 :             : /**
     512                 :             :  * @dev Library of standard hash functions.
     513                 :             :  *
     514                 :             :  * _Available since v5.1._
     515                 :             :  */
     516                 :             : library Hashes {
     517                 :             :     /**
     518                 :             :      * @dev Commutative Keccak256 hash of a sorted pair of bytes32. Frequently used when working with merkle proofs.
     519                 :             :      *
     520                 :             :      * NOTE: Equivalent to the `standardNodeHash` in our https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/merkle-tree[JavaScript library].
     521                 :             :      */
     522                 :          14 :     function commutativeKeccak256(bytes32 a, bytes32 b) internal pure returns (bytes32) {
     523                 :          14 :         return a < b ? _efficientKeccak256(a, b) : _efficientKeccak256(b, a);
     524                 :             :     }
     525                 :             : 
     526                 :             :     /**
     527                 :             :      * @dev Implementation of keccak256(abi.encode(a, b)) that doesn't allocate or expand memory.
     528                 :             :      */
     529                 :          14 :     function _efficientKeccak256(bytes32 a, bytes32 b) private pure returns (bytes32 value) {
     530                 :             :         assembly ("memory-safe") {
     531                 :           0 :             mstore(0x00, a)
     532                 :           0 :             mstore(0x20, b)
     533                 :           0 :             value := keccak256(0x00, 0x40)
     534                 :             :         }
     535                 :             :     }
     536                 :             : }
     537                 :             : 
     538                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/utils/introspection/IERC165.sol
     539                 :             : 
     540                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (utils/introspection/IERC165.sol)
     541                 :             : 
     542                 :             : /**
     543                 :             :  * @dev Interface of the ERC-165 standard, as defined in the
     544                 :             :  * https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-165[ERC].
     545                 :             :  *
     546                 :             :  * Implementers can declare support of contract interfaces, which can then be
     547                 :             :  * queried by others ({ERC165Checker}).
     548                 :             :  *
     549                 :             :  * For an implementation, see {ERC165}.
     550                 :             :  */
     551                 :             : interface IERC165 {
     552                 :             :     /**
     553                 :             :      * @dev Returns true if this contract implements the interface defined by
     554                 :             :      * `interfaceId`. See the corresponding
     555                 :             :      * https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-165#how-interfaces-are-identified[ERC section]
     556                 :             :      * to learn more about how these ids are created.
     557                 :             :      *
     558                 :             :      * This function call must use less than 30 000 gas.
     559                 :             :      */
     560                 :             :     function supportsInterface(bytes4 interfaceId) external view returns (bool);
     561                 :             : }
     562                 :             : 
     563                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/token/ERC20/IERC20.sol
     564                 :             : 
     565                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (token/ERC20/IERC20.sol)
     566                 :             : 
     567                 :             : /**
     568                 :             :  * @dev Interface of the ERC-20 standard as defined in the ERC.
     569                 :             :  */
     570                 :             : interface IERC20 {
     571                 :             :     /**
     572                 :             :      * @dev Emitted when `value` tokens are moved from one account (`from`) to
     573                 :             :      * another (`to`).
     574                 :             :      *
     575                 :             :      * Note that `value` may be zero.
     576                 :             :      */
     577                 :             :     event Transfer(address indexed from, address indexed to, uint256 value);
     578                 :             : 
     579                 :             :     /**
     580                 :             :      * @dev Emitted when the allowance of a `spender` for an `owner` is set by
     581                 :             :      * a call to {approve}. `value` is the new allowance.
     582                 :             :      */
     583                 :             :     event Approval(address indexed owner, address indexed spender, uint256 value);
     584                 :             : 
     585                 :             :     /**
     586                 :             :      * @dev Returns the value of tokens in existence.
     587                 :             :      */
     588                 :             :     function totalSupply() external view returns (uint256);
     589                 :             : 
     590                 :             :     /**
     591                 :             :      * @dev Returns the value of tokens owned by `account`.
     592                 :             :      */
     593                 :             :     function balanceOf(address account) external view returns (uint256);
     594                 :             : 
     595                 :             :     /**
     596                 :             :      * @dev Moves a `value` amount of tokens from the caller's account to `to`.
     597                 :             :      *
     598                 :             :      * Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
     599                 :             :      *
     600                 :             :      * Emits a {Transfer} event.
     601                 :             :      */
     602                 :             :     function transfer(address to, uint256 value) external returns (bool);
     603                 :             : 
     604                 :             :     /**
     605                 :             :      * @dev Returns the remaining number of tokens that `spender` will be
     606                 :             :      * allowed to spend on behalf of `owner` through {transferFrom}. This is
     607                 :             :      * zero by default.
     608                 :             :      *
     609                 :             :      * This value changes when {approve} or {transferFrom} are called.
     610                 :             :      */
     611                 :             :     function allowance(address owner, address spender) external view returns (uint256);
     612                 :             : 
     613                 :             :     /**
     614                 :             :      * @dev Sets a `value` amount of tokens as the allowance of `spender` over the
     615                 :             :      * caller's tokens.
     616                 :             :      *
     617                 :             :      * Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
     618                 :             :      *
     619                 :             :      * IMPORTANT: Beware that changing an allowance with this method brings the risk
     620                 :             :      * that someone may use both the old and the new allowance by unfortunate
     621                 :             :      * transaction ordering. One possible solution to mitigate this race
     622                 :             :      * condition is to first reduce the spender's allowance to 0 and set the
     623                 :             :      * desired value afterwards:
     624                 :             :      * https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/20#issuecomment-263524729
     625                 :             :      *
     626                 :             :      * Emits an {Approval} event.
     627                 :             :      */
     628                 :             :     function approve(address spender, uint256 value) external returns (bool);
     629                 :             : 
     630                 :             :     /**
     631                 :             :      * @dev Moves a `value` amount of tokens from `from` to `to` using the
     632                 :             :      * allowance mechanism. `value` is then deducted from the caller's
     633                 :             :      * allowance.
     634                 :             :      *
     635                 :             :      * Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
     636                 :             :      *
     637                 :             :      * Emits a {Transfer} event.
     638                 :             :      */
     639                 :             :     function transferFrom(address from, address to, uint256 value) external returns (bool);
     640                 :             : }
     641                 :             : 
     642                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/token/ERC20/extensions/IERC20Permit.sol
     643                 :             : 
     644                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (token/ERC20/extensions/IERC20Permit.sol)
     645                 :             : 
     646                 :             : /**
     647                 :             :  * @dev Interface of the ERC-20 Permit extension allowing approvals to be made via signatures, as defined in
     648                 :             :  * https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2612[ERC-2612].
     649                 :             :  *
     650                 :             :  * Adds the {permit} method, which can be used to change an account's ERC-20 allowance (see {IERC20-allowance}) by
     651                 :             :  * presenting a message signed by the account. By not relying on {IERC20-approve}, the token holder account doesn't
     652                 :             :  * need to send a transaction, and thus is not required to hold Ether at all.
     653                 :             :  *
     654                 :             :  * ==== Security Considerations
     655                 :             :  *
     656                 :             :  * There are two important considerations concerning the use of `permit`. The first is that a valid permit signature
     657                 :             :  * expresses an allowance, and it should not be assumed to convey additional meaning. In particular, it should not be
     658                 :             :  * considered as an intention to spend the allowance in any specific way. The second is that because permits have
     659                 :             :  * built-in replay protection and can be submitted by anyone, they can be frontrun. A protocol that uses permits should
     660                 :             :  * take this into consideration and allow a `permit` call to fail. Combining these two aspects, a pattern that may be
     661                 :             :  * generally recommended is:
     662                 :             :  *
     663                 :             :  * ```solidity
     664                 :             :  * function doThingWithPermit(..., uint256 value, uint256 deadline, uint8 v, bytes32 r, bytes32 s) public {
     665                 :             :  *     try token.permit(msg.sender, address(this), value, deadline, v, r, s) {} catch {}
     666                 :             :  *     doThing(..., value);
     667                 :             :  * }
     668                 :             :  *
     669                 :             :  * function doThing(..., uint256 value) public {
     670                 :             :  *     token.safeTransferFrom(msg.sender, address(this), value);
     671                 :             :  *     ...
     672                 :             :  * }
     673                 :             :  * ```
     674                 :             :  *
     675                 :             :  * Observe that: 1) `msg.sender` is used as the owner, leaving no ambiguity as to the signer intent, and 2) the use of
     676                 :             :  * `try/catch` allows the permit to fail and makes the code tolerant to frontrunning. (See also
     677                 :             :  * {SafeERC20-safeTransferFrom}).
     678                 :             :  *
     679                 :             :  * Additionally, note that smart contract wallets (such as Argent or Safe) are not able to produce permit signatures, so
     680                 :             :  * contracts should have entry points that don't rely on permit.
     681                 :             :  */
     682                 :             : interface IERC20Permit {
     683                 :             :     /**
     684                 :             :      * @dev Sets `value` as the allowance of `spender` over ``owner``'s tokens,
     685                 :             :      * given ``owner``'s signed approval.
     686                 :             :      *
     687                 :             :      * IMPORTANT: The same issues {IERC20-approve} has related to transaction
     688                 :             :      * ordering also apply here.
     689                 :             :      *
     690                 :             :      * Emits an {Approval} event.
     691                 :             :      *
     692                 :             :      * Requirements:
     693                 :             :      *
     694                 :             :      * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.
     695                 :             :      * - `deadline` must be a timestamp in the future.
     696                 :             :      * - `v`, `r` and `s` must be a valid `secp256k1` signature from `owner`
     697                 :             :      * over the EIP712-formatted function arguments.
     698                 :             :      * - the signature must use ``owner``'s current nonce (see {nonces}).
     699                 :             :      *
     700                 :             :      * For more information on the signature format, see the
     701                 :             :      * https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2612#specification[relevant EIP
     702                 :             :      * section].
     703                 :             :      *
     704                 :             :      * CAUTION: See Security Considerations above.
     705                 :             :      */
     706                 :             :     function permit(
     707                 :             :         address owner,
     708                 :             :         address spender,
     709                 :             :         uint256 value,
     710                 :             :         uint256 deadline,
     711                 :             :         uint8 v,
     712                 :             :         bytes32 r,
     713                 :             :         bytes32 s
     714                 :             :     ) external;
     715                 :             : 
     716                 :             :     /**
     717                 :             :      * @dev Returns the current nonce for `owner`. This value must be
     718                 :             :      * included whenever a signature is generated for {permit}.
     719                 :             :      *
     720                 :             :      * Every successful call to {permit} increases ``owner``'s nonce by one. This
     721                 :             :      * prevents a signature from being used multiple times.
     722                 :             :      */
     723                 :             :     function nonces(address owner) external view returns (uint256);
     724                 :             : 
     725                 :             :     /**
     726                 :             :      * @dev Returns the domain separator used in the encoding of the signature for {permit}, as defined by {EIP712}.
     727                 :             :      */
     728                 :             :     // solhint-disable-next-line func-name-mixedcase
     729                 :             :     function DOMAIN_SEPARATOR() external view returns (bytes32);
     730                 :             : }
     731                 :             : 
     732                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/interfaces/IERC5267.sol
     733                 :             : 
     734                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.0.0) (interfaces/IERC5267.sol)
     735                 :             : 
     736                 :             : interface IERC5267 {
     737                 :             :     /**
     738                 :             :      * @dev MAY be emitted to signal that the domain could have changed.
     739                 :             :      */
     740                 :             :     event EIP712DomainChanged();
     741                 :             : 
     742                 :             :     /**
     743                 :             :      * @dev returns the fields and values that describe the domain separator used by this contract for EIP-712
     744                 :             :      * signature.
     745                 :             :      */
     746                 :             :     function eip712Domain()
     747                 :             :         external
     748                 :             :         view
     749                 :             :         returns (
     750                 :             :             bytes1 fields,
     751                 :             :             string memory name,
     752                 :             :             string memory version,
     753                 :             :             uint256 chainId,
     754                 :             :             address verifyingContract,
     755                 :             :             bytes32 salt,
     756                 :             :             uint256[] memory extensions
     757                 :             :         );
     758                 :             : }
     759                 :             :

     764                 :             :     uint32 configType;
     765                 :             :     bytes config;
     766                 :             : }

     862                 :             : // node_modules/@layerzerolabs/lz-evm-protocol-v2/contracts/interfaces/IMessagingComposer.sol
     863                 :             : 
     864                 :             : interface IMessagingComposer {
     865                 :             :     event ComposeSent(address from, address to, bytes32 guid, uint16 index, bytes message);
     866                 :             :     event ComposeDelivered(address from, address to, bytes32 guid, uint16 index);
     867                 :             :     event LzComposeAlert(
     868                 :             :         address indexed from,
     869                 :             :         address indexed to,
     870                 :             :         address indexed executor,
     871                 :             :         bytes32 guid,
     872                 :             :         uint16 index,
     873                 :             :         uint256 gas,
     874                 :             :         uint256 value,
     875                 :             :         bytes message,
     876                 :             :         bytes extraData,
     877                 :             :         bytes reason
     878                 :             :     );
     879                 :             : 
     880                 :             :     function composeQueue(
     881                 :             :         address _from,
     882                 :             :         address _to,
     883                 :             :         bytes32 _guid,
     884                 :             :         uint16 _index
     885                 :             :     ) external view returns (bytes32 messageHash);
     886                 :             :

    1010                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/utils/Nonces.sol
    1011                 :             : 
    1012                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.0.0) (utils/Nonces.sol)
    1013                 :             : 
    1014                 :             : /**
    1015                 :             :  * @dev Provides tracking nonces for addresses. Nonces will only increment.
    1016                 :             :  */
    1017                 :             : abstract contract Nonces {
    1018                 :             :     /**
    1019                 :             :      * @dev The nonce used for an `account` is not the expected current nonce.
    1020                 :             :      */
    1021                 :             :     error InvalidAccountNonce(address account, uint256 currentNonce);
    1022                 :             : 
    1023                 :             :     mapping(address account => uint256) private _nonces;
    1024                 :             : 
    1025                 :             :     /**
    1026                 :             :      * @dev Returns the next unused nonce for an address.
    1027                 :             :      */
    1028                 :           0 :     function nonces(address owner) public view virtual returns (uint256) {
    1029                 :           0 :         return _nonces[owner];
    1030                 :             :     }
    1031                 :             : 
    1032                 :             :     /**
    1033                 :             :      * @dev Consumes a nonce.
    1034                 :             :      *
    1035                 :             :      * Returns the current value and increments nonce.
    1036                 :             :      */
    1037                 :           0 :     function _useNonce(address owner) internal virtual returns (uint256) {
    1038                 :             :         // For each account, the nonce has an initial value of 0, can only be incremented by one, and cannot be
    1039                 :             :         // decremented or reset. This guarantees that the nonce never overflows.
    1040                 :             :         unchecked {
    1041                 :             :             // It is important to do x++ and not ++x here.
    1042                 :           0 :             return _nonces[owner]++;
    1043                 :             :         }
    1044                 :             :     }
    1045                 :             : 
    1046                 :             :     /**
    1047                 :             :      * @dev Same as {_useNonce} but checking that `nonce` is the next valid for `owner`.
    1048                 :             :      */
    1049                 :           0 :     function _useCheckedNonce(address owner, uint256 nonce) internal virtual {
    1050                 :           0 :         uint256 current = _useNonce(owner);
    1051            [ # ]:           0 :         if (nonce != current) {
    1052                 :           0 :             revert InvalidAccountNonce(owner, current);
    1053                 :             :         }
    1054                 :             :     }
    1055                 :             : }

    1057                 :             : // node_modules/@layerzerolabs/oft-evm/contracts/libs/OFTComposeMsgCodec.sol
    1058                 :             : 
    1059                 :             : library OFTComposeMsgCodec {
    1060                 :             :     // Offset constants for decoding composed messages
    1061                 :             :     uint8 private constant NONCE_OFFSET = 8;
    1062                 :             :     uint8 private constant SRC_EID_OFFSET = 12;
    1063                 :             :     uint8 private constant AMOUNT_LD_OFFSET = 44;
    1064                 :             :     uint8 private constant COMPOSE_FROM_OFFSET = 76;
    1065                 :             : 
    1066                 :             :     /**
    1067                 :             :      * @dev Encodes a OFT composed message.
    1068                 :             :      * @param _nonce The nonce value.
    1069                 :             :      * @param _srcEid The source endpoint ID.
    1070                 :             :      * @param _amountLD The amount in local decimals.
    1071                 :             :      * @param _composeMsg The composed message.
    1072                 :             :      * @return _msg The encoded Composed message.
    1073                 :             :      */
    1074                 :           0 :     function encode(
    1075                 :             :         uint64 _nonce,
    1076                 :             :         uint32 _srcEid,
    1077                 :             :         uint256 _amountLD,
    1078                 :             :         bytes memory _composeMsg // 0x[composeFrom][composeMsg]
    1079                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (bytes memory _msg) {
    1080                 :           0 :         _msg = abi.encodePacked(_nonce, _srcEid, _amountLD, _composeMsg);
    1081                 :             :     }
    1082                 :             : 
    1083                 :             :     /**
    1084                 :             :      * @dev Retrieves the nonce for the composed message.
    1085                 :             :      * @param _msg The message.
    1086                 :             :      * @return The nonce value.
    1087                 :             :      */
    1088                 :           0 :     function nonce(bytes calldata _msg) internal pure returns (uint64) {
    1089                 :           0 :         return uint64(bytes8(_msg[:NONCE_OFFSET]));
    1090                 :             :     }
    1091                 :             : 
    1092                 :             :     /**
    1093                 :             :      * @dev Retrieves the source endpoint ID for the composed message.
    1094                 :             :      * @param _msg The message.
    1095                 :             :      * @return The source endpoint ID.
    1096                 :             :      */
    1097                 :           0 :     function srcEid(bytes calldata _msg) internal pure returns (uint32) {
    1098                 :           0 :         return uint32(bytes4(_msg[NONCE_OFFSET:SRC_EID_OFFSET]));
    1099                 :             :     }
    1100                 :             : 
    1101                 :             :     /**
    1102                 :             :      * @dev Retrieves the amount in local decimals from the composed message.
    1103                 :             :      * @param _msg The message.
    1104                 :             :      * @return The amount in local decimals.
    1105                 :             :      */
    1106                 :           0 :     function amountLD(bytes calldata _msg) internal pure returns (uint256) {
    1107                 :           0 :         return uint256(bytes32(_msg[SRC_EID_OFFSET:AMOUNT_LD_OFFSET]));
    1108                 :             :     }
    1109                 :             : 
    1110                 :             :     /**
    1111                 :             :      * @dev Retrieves the composeFrom value from the composed message.
    1112                 :             :      * @param _msg The message.
    1113                 :             :      * @return The composeFrom value.
    1114                 :             :      */
    1115                 :           0 :     function composeFrom(bytes calldata _msg) internal pure returns (bytes32) {
    1116                 :           0 :         return bytes32(_msg[AMOUNT_LD_OFFSET:COMPOSE_FROM_OFFSET]);
    1117                 :             :     }
    1118                 :             : 
    1119                 :             :     /**
    1120                 :             :      * @dev Retrieves the composed message.

    1122                 :             :      * @return The composed message.
    1123                 :             :      */
    1124                 :           0 :     function composeMsg(bytes calldata _msg) internal pure returns (bytes memory) {
    1125                 :           0 :         return _msg[COMPOSE_FROM_OFFSET:];
    1126                 :             :     }
    1127                 :             : 
    1128                 :             :     /**

    1132                 :             :      */

    1134                 :           0 :         return bytes32(uint256(uint160(_addr)));

    1147                 :             : // node_modules/@layerzerolabs/oft-evm/contracts/libs/OFTMsgCodec.sol
    1148                 :             : 
    1149                 :             : library OFTMsgCodec {
    1150                 :             :     // Offset constants for encoding and decoding OFT messages
    1151                 :             :     uint8 private constant SEND_TO_OFFSET = 32;
    1152                 :             :     uint8 private constant SEND_AMOUNT_SD_OFFSET = 40;
    1153                 :             : 
    1154                 :             :     /**
    1155                 :             :      * @dev Encodes an OFT LayerZero message.
    1156                 :             :      * @param _sendTo The recipient address.
    1157                 :             :      * @param _amountShared The amount in shared decimals.
    1158                 :             :      * @param _composeMsg The composed message.
    1159                 :             :      * @return _msg The encoded message.
    1160                 :             :      * @return hasCompose A boolean indicating whether the message has a composed payload.
    1161                 :             :      */
    1162                 :           0 :     function encode(
    1163                 :             :         bytes32 _sendTo,
    1164                 :             :         uint64 _amountShared,
    1165                 :             :         bytes memory _composeMsg
    1166                 :             :     ) internal view returns (bytes memory _msg, bool hasCompose) {
    1167                 :           0 :         hasCompose = _composeMsg.length > 0;
    1168                 :             :         // @dev Remote chains will want to know the composed function caller ie. msg.sender on the src.
    1169                 :           0 :         _msg = hasCompose
    1170                 :             :             ? abi.encodePacked(_sendTo, _amountShared, addressToBytes32(msg.sender), _composeMsg)
    1171                 :             :             : abi.encodePacked(_sendTo, _amountShared);
    1172                 :             :     }
    1173                 :             : 
    1174                 :             :     /**
    1175                 :             :      * @dev Checks if the OFT message is composed.
    1176                 :             :      * @param _msg The OFT message.
    1177                 :             :      * @return A boolean indicating whether the message is composed.
    1178                 :             :      */
    1179                 :           0 :     function isComposed(bytes calldata _msg) internal pure returns (bool) {
    1180                 :           0 :         return _msg.length > SEND_AMOUNT_SD_OFFSET;
    1181                 :             :     }
    1182                 :             : 
    1183                 :             :     /**
    1184                 :             :      * @dev Retrieves the recipient address from the OFT message.
    1185                 :             :      * @param _msg The OFT message.
    1186                 :             :      * @return The recipient address.
    1187                 :             :      */
    1188                 :           0 :     function sendTo(bytes calldata _msg) internal pure returns (bytes32) {
    1189                 :           0 :         return bytes32(_msg[:SEND_TO_OFFSET]);
    1190                 :             :     }
    1191                 :             : 
    1192                 :             :     /**
    1193                 :             :      * @dev Retrieves the amount in shared decimals from the OFT message.
    1194                 :             :      * @param _msg The OFT message.
    1195                 :             :      * @return The amount in shared decimals.
    1196                 :             :      */
    1197                 :           0 :     function amountSD(bytes calldata _msg) internal pure returns (uint64) {
    1198                 :           0 :         return uint64(bytes8(_msg[SEND_TO_OFFSET:SEND_AMOUNT_SD_OFFSET]));
    1199                 :             :     }
    1200                 :             : 
    1201                 :             :     /**
    1202                 :             :      * @dev Retrieves the composed message from the OFT message.
    1203                 :             :      * @param _msg The OFT message.
    1204                 :             :      * @return The composed message.
    1205                 :             :      */
    1206                 :           0 :     function composeMsg(bytes calldata _msg) internal pure returns (bytes memory) {
    1207                 :           0 :         return _msg[SEND_AMOUNT_SD_OFFSET:];
    1208                 :             :     }
    1209                 :             : 
    1210                 :             :     /**
    1211                 :             :      * @dev Converts an address to bytes32.

    1223                 :             :      */
    1224                 :           0 :     function bytes32ToAddress(bytes32 _b) internal pure returns (address) {
