    1228                 :             : 
    1229                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/utils/Panic.sol
    1230                 :             : 
    1231                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (utils/Panic.sol)
    1232                 :             : 
    1233                 :             : /**
    1234                 :             :  * @dev Helper library for emitting standardized panic codes.
    1235                 :             :  *
    1236                 :             :  * ```solidity
    1237                 :             :  * contract Example {
    1238                 :             :  *      using Panic for uint256;
    1239                 :             :  *
    1240                 :             :  *      // Use any of the declared internal constants
    1241                 :             :  *      function foo() { Panic.GENERIC.panic(); }
    1242                 :             :  *
    1243                 :             :  *      // Alternatively
    1244                 :             :  *      function foo() { Panic.panic(Panic.GENERIC); }
    1245                 :             :  * }
    1246                 :             :  * ```
    1247                 :             :  *
    1248                 :             :  * Follows the list from https://github.com/ethereum/solidity/blob/v0.8.24/libsolutil/ErrorCodes.h[libsolutil].
    1249                 :             :  *
    1250                 :             :  * _Available since v5.1._
    1251                 :             :  */
    1252                 :             : // slither-disable-next-line unused-state
    1253                 :             : library Panic {
    1254                 :             :     /// @dev generic / unspecified error
    1255                 :             :     uint256 internal constant GENERIC = 0x00;
    1256                 :             :     /// @dev used by the assert() builtin
    1257                 :             :     uint256 internal constant ASSERT = 0x01;
    1258                 :             :     /// @dev arithmetic underflow or overflow
    1259                 :             :     uint256 internal constant UNDER_OVERFLOW = 0x11;
    1260                 :             :     /// @dev division or modulo by zero
    1261                 :             :     uint256 internal constant DIVISION_BY_ZERO = 0x12;
    1262                 :             :     /// @dev enum conversion error
    1263                 :             :     uint256 internal constant ENUM_CONVERSION_ERROR = 0x21;
    1264                 :             :     /// @dev invalid encoding in storage
    1265                 :             :     uint256 internal constant STORAGE_ENCODING_ERROR = 0x22;
    1266                 :             :     /// @dev empty array pop
    1267                 :             :     uint256 internal constant EMPTY_ARRAY_POP = 0x31;
    1268                 :             :     /// @dev array out of bounds access
    1269                 :             :     uint256 internal constant ARRAY_OUT_OF_BOUNDS = 0x32;
    1270                 :             :     /// @dev resource error (too large allocation or too large array)
    1271                 :             :     uint256 internal constant RESOURCE_ERROR = 0x41;
    1272                 :             :     /// @dev calling invalid internal function
    1273                 :             :     uint256 internal constant INVALID_INTERNAL_FUNCTION = 0x51;
    1274                 :             : 
    1275                 :             :     /// @dev Reverts with a panic code. Recommended to use with
    1276                 :             :     /// the internal constants with predefined codes.
    1277                 :           0 :     function panic(uint256 code) internal pure {
    1278                 :             :         assembly ("memory-safe") {
    1279                 :           0 :             mstore(0x00, 0x4e487b71)
    1280                 :           0 :             mstore(0x20, code)
    1281                 :           0 :             revert(0x1c, 0x24)
    1282                 :             :         }
    1283                 :             :     }
    1284                 :             : }
    1285                 :             : 
    1286                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/utils/math/SafeCast.sol
    1287                 :             : 
    1288                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (utils/math/SafeCast.sol)
    1289                 :             : // This file was procedurally generated from scripts/generate/templates/SafeCast.js.
    1290                 :             : 
    1291                 :             : /**
    1292                 :             :  * @dev Wrappers over Solidity's uintXX/intXX/bool casting operators with added overflow
    1293                 :             :  * checks.
    1294                 :             :  *
    1295                 :             :  * Downcasting from uint256/int256 in Solidity does not revert on overflow. This can
    1296                 :             :  * easily result in undesired exploitation or bugs, since developers usually
    1297                 :             :  * assume that overflows raise errors. `SafeCast` restores this intuition by
    1298                 :             :  * reverting the transaction when such an operation overflows.
    1299                 :             :  *
    1300                 :             :  * Using this library instead of the unchecked operations eliminates an entire
    1301                 :             :  * class of bugs, so it's recommended to use it always.
    1302                 :             :  */
    1303                 :             : library SafeCast {
    1304                 :             :     /**
    1305                 :             :      * @dev Value doesn't fit in an uint of `bits` size.
    1306                 :             :      */
    1307                 :             :     error SafeCastOverflowedUintDowncast(uint8 bits, uint256 value);
    1308                 :             : 
    1309                 :             :     /**
    1310                 :             :      * @dev An int value doesn't fit in an uint of `bits` size.
    1311                 :             :      */
    1312                 :             :     error SafeCastOverflowedIntToUint(int256 value);
    1313                 :             : 
    1314                 :             :     /**
    1315                 :             :      * @dev Value doesn't fit in an int of `bits` size.
    1316                 :             :      */
    1317                 :             :     error SafeCastOverflowedIntDowncast(uint8 bits, int256 value);
    1318                 :             : 
    1319                 :             :     /**
    1320                 :             :      * @dev An uint value doesn't fit in an int of `bits` size.
    1321                 :             :      */
    1322                 :             :     error SafeCastOverflowedUintToInt(uint256 value);
    1323                 :             : 
    1324                 :             :     /**
    1325                 :             :      * @dev Returns the downcasted uint248 from uint256, reverting on
    1326                 :             :      * overflow (when the input is greater than largest uint248).
    1327                 :             :      *
    1328                 :             :      * Counterpart to Solidity's `uint248` operator.
    1329                 :             :      *
    1330                 :             :      * Requirements:
    1331                 :             :      *
    1332                 :             :      * - input must fit into 248 bits
    1333                 :             :      */
    1334                 :           0 :     function toUint248(uint256 value) internal pure returns (uint248) {
    1335            [ # ]:           0 :         if (value > type(uint248).max) {
    1336                 :           0 :             revert SafeCastOverflowedUintDowncast(248, value);
    1337                 :             :         }
    1338                 :           0 :         return uint248(value);
    1339                 :             :     }
    1340                 :             : 
    1341                 :             :     /**
    1342                 :             :      * @dev Returns the downcasted uint240 from uint256, reverting on
    1343                 :             :      * overflow (when the input is greater than largest uint240).
    1344                 :             :      *
    1345                 :             :      * Counterpart to Solidity's `uint240` operator.
    1346                 :             :      *
    1347                 :             :      * Requirements:

    1831                 :           0 :         return uint16(value);
    1832                 :             :     }
    1833                 :             : 
    1834                 :             :     /**
    1835                 :             :      * @dev Returns the downcasted uint8 from uint256, reverting on
    1836                 :             :      * overflow (when the input is greater than largest uint8).
    1837                 :             :      *
    1838                 :             :      * Counterpart to Solidity's `uint8` operator.
    1839                 :             :      *
    1840                 :             :      * Requirements:
    1841                 :             :      *
    1842                 :             :      * - input must fit into 8 bits
    1843                 :             :      */
    1844                 :           0 :     function toUint8(uint256 value) internal pure returns (uint8) {
    1845            [ # ]:           0 :         if (value > type(uint8).max) {
    1846                 :           0 :             revert SafeCastOverflowedUintDowncast(8, value);
    1847                 :             :         }
    1848                 :           0 :         return uint8(value);
    1849                 :             :     }
    1850                 :             : 
    1851                 :             :     /**
    1852                 :             :      * @dev Converts a signed int256 into an unsigned uint256.
    1853                 :             :      *
    1854                 :             :      * Requirements:
    1855                 :             :      *
    1856                 :             :      * - input must be greater than or equal to 0.
    1857                 :             :      */
    1858                 :           0 :     function toUint256(int256 value) internal pure returns (uint256) {
    1859            [ # ]:           0 :         if (value < 0) {
    1860                 :           0 :             revert SafeCastOverflowedIntToUint(value);
    1861                 :             :         }
    1862                 :           0 :         return uint256(value);
    1863                 :             :     }

    2314                 :             : 
    2315                 :             :     /**
    2316                 :             :      * @dev Returns the downcasted int48 from int256, reverting on
    2317                 :             :      * overflow (when the input is less than smallest int48 or
    2318                 :             :      * greater than largest int48).
    2319                 :             :      *
    2320                 :             :      * Counterpart to Solidity's `int48` operator.
    2321                 :             :      *
    2322                 :             :      * Requirements:
    2323                 :             :      *
    2324                 :             :      * - input must fit into 48 bits
    2325                 :             :      */
    2326                 :           0 :     function toInt48(int256 value) internal pure returns (int48 downcasted) {
    2327                 :           0 :         downcasted = int48(value);
    2328            [ # ]:           0 :         if (downcasted != value) {
    2329                 :           0 :             revert SafeCastOverflowedIntDowncast(48, value);
    2330                 :             :         }
    2331                 :             :     }
    2332                 :             : 
    2333                 :             :     /**
    2334                 :             :      * @dev Returns the downcasted int40 from int256, reverting on
    2335                 :             :      * overflow (when the input is less than smallest int40 or
    2336                 :             :      * greater than largest int40).
    2337                 :             :      *
    2338                 :             :      * Counterpart to Solidity's `int40` operator.
    2339                 :             :      *
    2340                 :             :      * Requirements:
    2341                 :             :      *
    2342                 :             :      * - input must fit into 40 bits
    2343                 :             :      */
    2344                 :           0 :     function toInt40(int256 value) internal pure returns (int40 downcasted) {
    2345                 :           0 :         downcasted = int40(value);
    2346            [ # ]:           0 :         if (downcasted != value) {
    2347                 :           0 :             revert SafeCastOverflowedIntDowncast(40, value);
    2348                 :             :         }
    2349                 :             :     }
    2350                 :             :

    2352                 :             :      * @dev Returns the downcasted int32 from int256, reverting on
    2353                 :             :      * overflow (when the input is less than smallest int32 or
    2354                 :             :      * greater than largest int32).

    2372                 :             :      * greater than largest int24).
    2373                 :             :      *

    2388                 :             :      * @dev Returns the downcasted int16 from int256, reverting on
    2389                 :             :      * overflow (when the input is less than smallest int16 or
    2390                 :             :      * greater than largest int16).
    2391                 :             :      *
    2392                 :             :      * Counterpart to Solidity's `int16` operator.
    2393                 :             :      *
    2394                 :             :      * Requirements:
    2395                 :             :      *
    2396                 :             :      * - input must fit into 16 bits
    2397                 :             :      */
    2398                 :           0 :     function toInt16(int256 value) internal pure returns (int16 downcasted) {
    2399                 :           0 :         downcasted = int16(value);
    2400            [ # ]:           0 :         if (downcasted != value) {
    2401                 :           0 :             revert SafeCastOverflowedIntDowncast(16, value);
    2402                 :             :         }
    2403                 :             :     }
    2404                 :             : 
    2405                 :             :     /**
    2406                 :             :      * @dev Returns the downcasted int8 from int256, reverting on
    2407                 :             :      * overflow (when the input is less than smallest int8 or
    2408                 :             :      * greater than largest int8).
    2409                 :             :      *
    2410                 :             :      * Counterpart to Solidity's `int8` operator.
    2411                 :             :      *
    2412                 :             :      * Requirements:
    2413                 :             :      *
    2414                 :             :      * - input must fit into 8 bits
    2415                 :             :      */
    2416                 :           0 :     function toInt8(int256 value) internal pure returns (int8 downcasted) {
    2417                 :           0 :         downcasted = int8(value);
    2418            [ # ]:           0 :         if (downcasted != value) {
    2419                 :           0 :             revert SafeCastOverflowedIntDowncast(8, value);
    2420                 :             :         }
    2421                 :             :     }
    2422                 :             : 
    2423                 :             :     /**
    2424                 :             :      * @dev Converts an unsigned uint256 into a signed int256.
    2425                 :             :      *
    2426                 :             :      * Requirements:
    2427                 :             :      *
    2428                 :             :      * - input must be less than or equal to maxInt256.
    2429                 :             :      */
    2430                 :           0 :     function toInt256(uint256 value) internal pure returns (int256) {
    2431                 :             :         // Note: Unsafe cast below is okay because `type(int256).max` is guaranteed to be positive
    2432            [ # ]:           0 :         if (value > uint256(type(int256).max)) {
    2433                 :           0 :             revert SafeCastOverflowedUintToInt(value);
    2434                 :             :         }
    2435                 :           0 :         return int256(value);
    2436                 :             :     }
    2437                 :             : 
    2438                 :             :     /**
    2439                 :             :      * @dev Cast a boolean (false or true) to a uint256 (0 or 1) with no jump.
    2440                 :             :      */
    2441                 :           0 :     function toUint(bool b) internal pure returns (uint256 u) {
    2442                 :             :         assembly ("memory-safe") {
    2443                 :           0 :             u := iszero(iszero(b))
    2444                 :             :         }
    2445                 :             :     }
    2446                 :             : }

    2448                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/utils/StorageSlot.sol
    2449                 :             : 
    2450                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (utils/StorageSlot.sol)
    2451                 :             : // This file was procedurally generated from scripts/generate/templates/StorageSlot.js.
    2452                 :             : 
    2453                 :             : /**
    2454                 :             :  * @dev Library for reading and writing primitive types to specific storage slots.
    2455                 :             :  *
    2456                 :             :  * Storage slots are often used to avoid storage conflict when dealing with upgradeable contracts.
    2457                 :             :  * This library helps with reading and writing to such slots without the need for inline assembly.
    2458                 :             :  *
    2459                 :             :  * The functions in this library return Slot structs that contain a `value` member that can be used to read or write.
    2460                 :             :  *
    2461                 :             :  * Example usage to set ERC-1967 implementation slot:
    2462                 :             :  * ```solidity
    2463                 :             :  * contract ERC1967 {
    2464                 :             :  *     // Define the slot. Alternatively, use the SlotDerivation library to derive the slot.
    2465                 :             :  *     bytes32 internal constant _IMPLEMENTATION_SLOT = 0x360894a13ba1a3210667c828492db98dca3e2076cc3735a920a3ca505d382bbc;
    2466                 :             :  *
    2467                 :             :  *     function _getImplementation() internal view returns (address) {
    2468                 :             :  *         return StorageSlot.getAddressSlot(_IMPLEMENTATION_SLOT).value;
    2469                 :             :  *     }
    2470                 :             :  *
    2471                 :             :  *     function _setImplementation(address newImplementation) internal {
    2472                 :             :  *         require(newImplementation.code.length > 0);
    2473                 :             :  *         StorageSlot.getAddressSlot(_IMPLEMENTATION_SLOT).value = newImplementation;
    2474                 :             :  *     }
    2475                 :             :  * }
    2476                 :             :  * ```
    2477                 :             :  *
    2478                 :             :  * TIP: Consider using this library along with {SlotDerivation}.
    2479                 :             :  */
    2480                 :             : library StorageSlot {
    2481                 :             :     struct AddressSlot {
    2482                 :             :         address value;
    2483                 :             :     }
    2484                 :             : 
    2485                 :             :     struct BooleanSlot {
    2486                 :             :         bool value;
    2487                 :             :     }
    2488                 :             :

    2490                 :             :         bytes32 value;
    2491                 :             :     }
    2492                 :             : 
    2493                 :             :     struct Uint256Slot {
    2494                 :             :         uint256 value;
    2495                 :             :     }
    2496                 :             : 
    2497                 :             :     struct Int256Slot {
    2498                 :             :         int256 value;
    2499                 :             :     }
    2500                 :             : 
    2501                 :             :     struct StringSlot {
    2502                 :             :         string value;
    2503                 :             :     }
    2504                 :             : 
    2505                 :             :     struct BytesSlot {
    2506                 :             :         bytes value;
    2507                 :             :     }
    2508                 :             : 
    2509                 :             :     /**
    2510                 :             :      * @dev Returns an `AddressSlot` with member `value` located at `slot`.
    2511                 :             :      */
    2512                 :           0 :     function getAddressSlot(bytes32 slot) internal pure returns (AddressSlot storage r) {
    2513                 :             :         assembly ("memory-safe") {
    2514                 :           0 :             r.slot := slot
    2515                 :             :         }
    2516                 :             :     }
    2517                 :             :

    2649                 :             :      * @param owner Address of the current owner of a token.

    2660                 :             :      * @dev Indicates an error related to the ownership over a particular token. Used in transfers.

    2762                 :             : 
    2763                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (token/ERC20/extensions/IERC20Metadata.sol)
    2764                 :             : 
    2765                 :             : /**
    2766                 :             :  * @dev Interface for the optional metadata functions from the ERC-20 standard.
    2767                 :             :  */
    2768                 :             : interface IERC20Metadata is IERC20 {
    2769                 :             :     /**
    2770                 :             :      * @dev Returns the name of the token.
    2771                 :             :      */
    2772                 :             :     function name() external view returns (string memory);
    2773                 :             : 
    2774                 :             :     /**
    2775                 :             :      * @dev Returns the symbol of the token.
    2776                 :             :      */
    2777                 :             :     function symbol() external view returns (string memory);
    2778                 :             : 
    2779                 :             :     /**
    2780                 :             :      * @dev Returns the decimals places of the token.
    2781                 :             :      */
    2782                 :             :     function decimals() external view returns (uint8);
    2783                 :             : }
    2784                 :             : 
    2785                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/utils/cryptography/MerkleProof.sol
    2786                 :             : 
    2787                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (utils/cryptography/MerkleProof.sol)
    2788                 :             : // This file was procedurally generated from scripts/generate/templates/MerkleProof.js.
    2789                 :             : 
    2790                 :             : /**
    2791                 :             :  * @dev These functions deal with verification of Merkle Tree proofs.
    2792                 :             :  *
    2793                 :             :  * The tree and the proofs can be generated using our
    2794                 :             :  * https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/merkle-tree[JavaScript library].
    2795                 :             :  * You will find a quickstart guide in the readme.
    2796                 :             :  *
    2797                 :             :  * WARNING: You should avoid using leaf values that are 64 bytes long prior to
    2798                 :             :  * hashing, or use a hash function other than keccak256 for hashing leaves.
    2799                 :             :  * This is because the concatenation of a sorted pair of internal nodes in
    2800                 :             :  * the Merkle tree could be reinterpreted as a leaf value.
    2801                 :             :  * OpenZeppelin's JavaScript library generates Merkle trees that are safe
    2802                 :             :  * against this attack out of the box.
    2803                 :             :  *
    2804                 :             :  * IMPORTANT: Consider memory side-effects when using custom hashing functions
    2805                 :             :  * that access memory in an unsafe way.
    2806                 :             :  *
    2807                 :             :  * NOTE: This library supports proof verification for merkle trees built using
    2808                 :             :  * custom _commutative_ hashing functions (i.e. `H(a, b) == H(b, a)`). Proving
    2809                 :             :  * leaf inclusion in trees built using non-commutative hashing functions requires
    2810                 :             :  * additional logic that is not supported by this library.
    2811                 :             :  */
    2812                 :             : library MerkleProof {
    2813                 :             :     /**
    2814                 :             :      *@dev The multiproof provided is not valid.
    2815                 :             :      */
    2816                 :             :     error MerkleProofInvalidMultiproof();
    2817                 :             : 
    2818                 :             :     /**
    2819                 :             :      * @dev Returns true if a `leaf` can be proved to be a part of a Merkle tree
    2820                 :             :      * defined by `root`. For this, a `proof` must be provided, containing
    2821                 :             :      * sibling hashes on the branch from the leaf to the root of the tree. Each
    2822                 :             :      * pair of leaves and each pair of pre-images are assumed to be sorted.
    2823                 :             :      *
    2824                 :             :      * This version handles proofs in memory with the default hashing function.
    2825                 :             :      */
    2826                 :          14 :     function verify(bytes32[] memory proof, bytes32 root, bytes32 leaf) internal pure returns (bool) {
    2827                 :          14 :         return processProof(proof, leaf) == root;
    2828                 :             :     }
    2829                 :             : 
    2830                 :             :     /**
    2831                 :             :      * @dev Returns the rebuilt hash obtained by traversing a Merkle tree up
    2832                 :             :      * from `leaf` using `proof`. A `proof` is valid if and only if the rebuilt
    2833                 :             :      * hash matches the root of the tree. When processing the proof, the pairs
    2834                 :             :      * of leaves & pre-images are assumed to be sorted.
    2835                 :             :      *
    2836                 :             :      * This version handles proofs in memory with the default hashing function.
    2837                 :             :      */
    2838                 :          14 :     function processProof(bytes32[] memory proof, bytes32 leaf) internal pure returns (bytes32) {
    2839                 :          14 :         bytes32 computedHash = leaf;
    2840                 :          14 :         for (uint256 i = 0; i < proof.length; i++) {
    2841                 :          14 :             computedHash = Hashes.commutativeKeccak256(computedHash, proof[i]);
    2842                 :             :         }
    2843                 :           0 :         return computedHash;
    2844                 :             :     }
    2845                 :             : 
    2846                 :             :     /**
    2847                 :             :      * @dev Returns true if a `leaf` can be proved to be a part of a Merkle tree
    2848                 :             :      * defined by `root`. For this, a `proof` must be provided, containing
    2849                 :             :      * sibling hashes on the branch from the leaf to the root of the tree. Each
    2850                 :             :      * pair of leaves and each pair of pre-images are assumed to be sorted.
    2851                 :             :      *
    2852                 :             :      * This version handles proofs in memory with a custom hashing function.
    2853                 :             :      */
    2854                 :           0 :     function verify(
    2855                 :             :         bytes32[] memory proof,
    2856                 :             :         bytes32 root,
    2857                 :             :         bytes32 leaf,
    2858                 :             :         function(bytes32, bytes32) view returns (bytes32) hasher
    2859                 :             :     ) internal view returns (bool) {
    2860                 :           0 :         return processProof(proof, leaf, hasher) == root;
    2861                 :             :     }
    2862                 :             : 
    2863                 :             :     /**
    2864                 :             :      * @dev Returns the rebuilt hash obtained by traversing a Merkle tree up
    2865                 :             :      * from `leaf` using `proof`. A `proof` is valid if and only if the rebuilt
    2866                 :             :      * hash matches the root of the tree. When processing the proof, the pairs
    2867                 :             :      * of leaves & pre-images are assumed to be sorted.
    2868                 :             :      *
    2869                 :             :      * This version handles proofs in memory with a custom hashing function.
    2870                 :             :      */
    2871                 :           0 :     function processProof(
    2872                 :             :         bytes32[] memory proof,
    2873                 :             :         bytes32 leaf,
    2874                 :             :         function(bytes32, bytes32) view returns (bytes32) hasher
    2875                 :             :     ) internal view returns (bytes32) {
    2876                 :           0 :         bytes32 computedHash = leaf;
    2877                 :           0 :         for (uint256 i = 0; i < proof.length; i++) {
    2878                 :           0 :             computedHash = hasher(computedHash, proof[i]);
    2879                 :             :         }
    2880                 :           0 :         return computedHash;
    2881                 :             :     }
    2882                 :             : 
    2883                 :             :     /**
    2884                 :             :      * @dev Returns true if a `leaf` can be proved to be a part of a Merkle tree
    2885                 :             :      * defined by `root`. For this, a `proof` must be provided, containing
    2886                 :             :      * sibling hashes on the branch from the leaf to the root of the tree. Each
    2887                 :             :      * pair of leaves and each pair of pre-images are assumed to be sorted.
    2888                 :             :      *
    2889                 :             :      * This version handles proofs in calldata with the default hashing function.
    2890                 :             :      */
    2891                 :           0 :     function verifyCalldata(bytes32[] calldata proof, bytes32 root, bytes32 leaf) internal pure returns (bool) {
    2892                 :           0 :         return processProofCalldata(proof, leaf) == root;
    2893                 :             :     }
    2894                 :             : 
    2895                 :             :     /**
    2896                 :             :      * @dev Returns the rebuilt hash obtained by traversing a Merkle tree up
    2897                 :             :      * from `leaf` using `proof`. A `proof` is valid if and only if the rebuilt
    2898                 :             :      * hash matches the root of the tree. When processing the proof, the pairs
    2899                 :             :      * of leaves & pre-images are assumed to be sorted.
    2900                 :             :      *
    2901                 :             :      * This version handles proofs in calldata with the default hashing function.
    2902                 :             :      */
    2903                 :           0 :     function processProofCalldata(bytes32[] calldata proof, bytes32 leaf) internal pure returns (bytes32) {
    2904                 :           0 :         bytes32 computedHash = leaf;
    2905                 :           0 :         for (uint256 i = 0; i < proof.length; i++) {
    2906                 :           0 :             computedHash = Hashes.commutativeKeccak256(computedHash, proof[i]);
    2907                 :             :         }
    2908                 :           0 :         return computedHash;
    2909                 :             :     }
    2910                 :             : 
    2911                 :             :     /**
    2912                 :             :      * @dev Returns true if a `leaf` can be proved to be a part of a Merkle tree
    2913                 :             :      * defined by `root`. For this, a `proof` must be provided, containing
    2914                 :             :      * sibling hashes on the branch from the leaf to the root of the tree. Each
    2915                 :             :      * pair of leaves and each pair of pre-images are assumed to be sorted.
    2916                 :             :      *
    2917                 :             :      * This version handles proofs in calldata with a custom hashing function.
    2918                 :             :      */
    2919                 :           0 :     function verifyCalldata(
    2920                 :             :         bytes32[] calldata proof,
    2921                 :             :         bytes32 root,
    2922                 :             :         bytes32 leaf,
    2923                 :             :         function(bytes32, bytes32) view returns (bytes32) hasher
    2924                 :             :     ) internal view returns (bool) {
    2925                 :           0 :         return processProofCalldata(proof, leaf, hasher) == root;
    2926                 :             :     }
    2927                 :             : 
    2928                 :             :     /**
    2929                 :             :      * @dev Returns the rebuilt hash obtained by traversing a Merkle tree up
    2930                 :             :      * from `leaf` using `proof`. A `proof` is valid if and only if the rebuilt
    2931                 :             :      * hash matches the root of the tree. When processing the proof, the pairs
    2932                 :             :      * of leaves & pre-images are assumed to be sorted.
    2933                 :             :      *
    2934                 :             :      * This version handles proofs in calldata with a custom hashing function.
    2935                 :             :      */
    2936                 :           0 :     function processProofCalldata(
    2937                 :             :         bytes32[] calldata proof,
    2938                 :             :         bytes32 leaf,
    2939                 :             :         function(bytes32, bytes32) view returns (bytes32) hasher
    2940                 :             :     ) internal view returns (bytes32) {
    2941                 :           0 :         bytes32 computedHash = leaf;
    2942                 :           0 :         for (uint256 i = 0; i < proof.length; i++) {
    2943                 :           0 :             computedHash = hasher(computedHash, proof[i]);
    2944                 :             :         }
    2945                 :           0 :         return computedHash;
    2946                 :             :     }
    2947                 :             : 
    2948                 :             :     /**
    2949                 :             :      * @dev Returns true if the `leaves` can be simultaneously proven to be a part of a Merkle tree defined by
    2950                 :             :      * `root`, according to `proof` and `proofFlags` as described in {processMultiProof}.
    2951                 :             :      *
    2952                 :             :      * This version handles multiproofs in memory with the default hashing function.
    2953                 :             :      *
    2954                 :             :      * CAUTION: Not all Merkle trees admit multiproofs. See {processMultiProof} for details.
    2955                 :             :      *
    2956                 :             :      * NOTE: Consider the case where `root == proof[0] && leaves.length == 0` as it will return `true`.
    2957                 :             :      * The `leaves` must be validated independently. See {processMultiProof}.
    2958                 :             :      */
    2959                 :           0 :     function multiProofVerify(
    2960                 :             :         bytes32[] memory proof,
    2961                 :             :         bool[] memory proofFlags,
    2962                 :             :         bytes32 root,
    2963                 :             :         bytes32[] memory leaves
    2964                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (bool) {
    2965                 :           0 :         return processMultiProof(proof, proofFlags, leaves) == root;
    2966                 :             :     }
    2967                 :             : 
    2968                 :             :     /**
    2969                 :             :      * @dev Returns the root of a tree reconstructed from `leaves` and sibling nodes in `proof`. The reconstruction
    2970                 :             :      * proceeds by incrementally reconstructing all inner nodes by combining a leaf/inner node with either another
    2971                 :             :      * leaf/inner node or a proof sibling node, depending on whether each `proofFlags` item is true or false
    2972                 :             :      * respectively.
    2973                 :             :      *
    2974                 :             :      * This version handles multiproofs in memory with the default hashing function.
    2975                 :             :      *
    2976                 :             :      * CAUTION: Not all Merkle trees admit multiproofs. To use multiproofs, it is sufficient to ensure that: 1) the tree
    2977                 :             :      * is complete (but not necessarily perfect), 2) the leaves to be proven are in the opposite order they are in the
    2978                 :             :      * tree (i.e., as seen from right to left starting at the deepest layer and continuing at the next layer).
    2979                 :             :      *
    2980                 :             :      * NOTE: The _empty set_ (i.e. the case where `proof.length == 1 && leaves.length == 0`) is considered a no-op,
    2981                 :             :      * and therefore a valid multiproof (i.e. it returns `proof[0]`). Consider disallowing this case if you're not
    2982                 :             :      * validating the leaves elsewhere.
    2983                 :             :      */
    2984                 :           0 :     function processMultiProof(
    2985                 :             :         bytes32[] memory proof,
    2986                 :             :         bool[] memory proofFlags,
    2987                 :             :         bytes32[] memory leaves
    2988                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (bytes32 merkleRoot) {
    2989                 :             :         // This function rebuilds the root hash by traversing the tree up from the leaves. The root is rebuilt by
    2990                 :             :         // consuming and producing values on a queue. The queue starts with the `leaves` array, then goes onto the
    2991                 :             :         // `hashes` array. At the end of the process, the last hash in the `hashes` array should contain the root of
    2992                 :             :         // the Merkle tree.
    2993                 :           0 :         uint256 leavesLen = leaves.length;
    2994                 :           0 :         uint256 proofFlagsLen = proofFlags.length;
    2995                 :             : 
    2996                 :             :         // Check proof validity.
    2997            [ # ]:           0 :         if (leavesLen + proof.length != proofFlagsLen + 1) {
    2998                 :           0 :             revert MerkleProofInvalidMultiproof();
    2999                 :             :         }
    3000                 :             : 
    3001                 :             :         // The xxxPos values are "pointers" to the next value to consume in each array. All accesses are done using
    3002                 :             :         // `xxx[xxxPos++]`, which return the current value and increment the pointer, thus mimicking a queue's "pop".
    3003                 :           0 :         bytes32[] memory hashes = new bytes32[](proofFlagsLen);
    3004                 :           0 :         uint256 leafPos = 0;
    3005                 :           0 :         uint256 hashPos = 0;
    3006                 :           0 :         uint256 proofPos = 0;
    3007                 :             :         // At each step, we compute the next hash using two values:
    3008                 :             :         // - a value from the "main queue". If not all leaves have been consumed, we get the next leaf, otherwise we
    3009                 :             :         //   get the next hash.
    3010                 :             :         // - depending on the flag, either another value from the "main queue" (merging branches) or an element from the
    3011                 :             :         //   `proof` array.
    3012                 :           0 :         for (uint256 i = 0; i < proofFlagsLen; i++) {
    3013                 :           0 :             bytes32 a = leafPos < leavesLen ? leaves[leafPos++] : hashes[hashPos++];
    3014                 :           0 :             bytes32 b = proofFlags[i]
    3015                 :             :                 ? (leafPos < leavesLen ? leaves[leafPos++] : hashes[hashPos++])
    3016                 :             :                 : proof[proofPos++];
    3017                 :           0 :             hashes[i] = Hashes.commutativeKeccak256(a, b);
    3018                 :             :         }
    3019                 :             : 
    3020         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (proofFlagsLen > 0) {
    3021            [ # ]:           0 :             if (proofPos != proof.length) {
    3022                 :           0 :                 revert MerkleProofInvalidMultiproof();
    3023                 :             :             }
    3024                 :             :             unchecked {
    3025                 :           0 :                 return hashes[proofFlagsLen - 1];
    3026                 :             :             }
    3027         [ #  # ]:           0 :         } else if (leavesLen > 0) {
    3028                 :           0 :             return leaves[0];
    3029                 :             :         } else {
    3030                 :           0 :             return proof[0];
    3031                 :             :         }
    3032                 :             :     }
    3033                 :             : 
    3034                 :             :     /**
    3035                 :             :      * @dev Returns true if the `leaves` can be simultaneously proven to be a part of a Merkle tree defined by
    3036                 :             :      * `root`, according to `proof` and `proofFlags` as described in {processMultiProof}.
    3037                 :             :      *
    3038                 :             :      * This version handles multiproofs in memory with a custom hashing function.
    3039                 :             :      *
    3040                 :             :      * CAUTION: Not all Merkle trees admit multiproofs. See {processMultiProof} for details.
    3041                 :             :      *
    3042                 :             :      * NOTE: Consider the case where `root == proof[0] && leaves.length == 0` as it will return `true`.
    3043                 :             :      * The `leaves` must be validated independently. See {processMultiProof}.
    3044                 :             :      */
    3045                 :           0 :     function multiProofVerify(
    3046                 :             :         bytes32[] memory proof,
    3047                 :             :         bool[] memory proofFlags,
    3048                 :             :         bytes32 root,
    3049                 :             :         bytes32[] memory leaves,
    3050                 :             :         function(bytes32, bytes32) view returns (bytes32) hasher
    3051                 :             :     ) internal view returns (bool) {
    3052                 :           0 :         return processMultiProof(proof, proofFlags, leaves, hasher) == root;
    3053                 :             :     }
    3054                 :             : 
    3055                 :             :     /**
    3056                 :             :      * @dev Returns the root of a tree reconstructed from `leaves` and sibling nodes in `proof`. The reconstruction
    3057                 :             :      * proceeds by incrementally reconstructing all inner nodes by combining a leaf/inner node with either another
    3058                 :             :      * leaf/inner node or a proof sibling node, depending on whether each `proofFlags` item is true or false
    3059                 :             :      * respectively.
    3060                 :             :      *
    3061                 :             :      * This version handles multiproofs in memory with a custom hashing function.
    3062                 :             :      *
    3063                 :             :      * CAUTION: Not all Merkle trees admit multiproofs. To use multiproofs, it is sufficient to ensure that: 1) the tree
    3064                 :             :      * is complete (but not necessarily perfect), 2) the leaves to be proven are in the opposite order they are in the
    3065                 :             :      * tree (i.e., as seen from right to left starting at the deepest layer and continuing at the next layer).
    3066                 :             :      *
    3067                 :             :      * NOTE: The _empty set_ (i.e. the case where `proof.length == 1 && leaves.length == 0`) is considered a no-op,
    3068                 :             :      * and therefore a valid multiproof (i.e. it returns `proof[0]`). Consider disallowing this case if you're not
    3069                 :             :      * validating the leaves elsewhere.
    3070                 :             :      */
    3071                 :           0 :     function processMultiProof(
    3072                 :             :         bytes32[] memory proof,
    3073                 :             :         bool[] memory proofFlags,
    3074                 :             :         bytes32[] memory leaves,
    3075                 :             :         function(bytes32, bytes32) view returns (bytes32) hasher
    3076                 :             :     ) internal view returns (bytes32 merkleRoot) {
    3077                 :             :         // This function rebuilds the root hash by traversing the tree up from the leaves. The root is rebuilt by
    3078                 :             :         // consuming and producing values on a queue. The queue starts with the `leaves` array, then goes onto the
    3079                 :             :         // `hashes` array. At the end of the process, the last hash in the `hashes` array should contain the root of
    3080                 :             :         // the Merkle tree.
    3081                 :           0 :         uint256 leavesLen = leaves.length;
    3082                 :           0 :         uint256 proofFlagsLen = proofFlags.length;
    3083                 :             : 
    3084                 :             :         // Check proof validity.
    3085            [ # ]:           0 :         if (leavesLen + proof.length != proofFlagsLen + 1) {
    3086                 :           0 :             revert MerkleProofInvalidMultiproof();
    3087                 :             :         }
    3088                 :             : 
    3089                 :             :         // The xxxPos values are "pointers" to the next value to consume in each array. All accesses are done using
    3090                 :             :         // `xxx[xxxPos++]`, which return the current value and increment the pointer, thus mimicking a queue's "pop".
    3091                 :           0 :         bytes32[] memory hashes = new bytes32[](proofFlagsLen);
    3092                 :           0 :         uint256 leafPos = 0;
    3093                 :           0 :         uint256 hashPos = 0;
    3094                 :           0 :         uint256 proofPos = 0;
    3095                 :             :         // At each step, we compute the next hash using two values:
    3096                 :             :         // - a value from the "main queue". If not all leaves have been consumed, we get the next leaf, otherwise we
    3097                 :             :         //   get the next hash.
    3098                 :             :         // - depending on the flag, either another value from the "main queue" (merging branches) or an element from the
    3099                 :             :         //   `proof` array.
    3100                 :           0 :         for (uint256 i = 0; i < proofFlagsLen; i++) {
    3101                 :           0 :             bytes32 a = leafPos < leavesLen ? leaves[leafPos++] : hashes[hashPos++];
    3102                 :           0 :             bytes32 b = proofFlags[i]
    3103                 :             :                 ? (leafPos < leavesLen ? leaves[leafPos++] : hashes[hashPos++])
    3104                 :             :                 : proof[proofPos++];
    3105                 :           0 :             hashes[i] = hasher(a, b);
    3106                 :             :         }
    3107                 :             : 
    3108         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (proofFlagsLen > 0) {
    3109            [ # ]:           0 :             if (proofPos != proof.length) {
    3110                 :           0 :                 revert MerkleProofInvalidMultiproof();
    3111                 :             :             }
    3112                 :             :             unchecked {
    3113                 :           0 :                 return hashes[proofFlagsLen - 1];
    3114                 :             :             }
    3115         [ #  # ]:           0 :         } else if (leavesLen > 0) {
    3116                 :           0 :             return leaves[0];
    3117                 :             :         } else {
    3118                 :           0 :             return proof[0];
    3119                 :             :         }
    3120                 :             :     }
    3121                 :             : 
    3122                 :             :     /**
    3123                 :             :      * @dev Returns true if the `leaves` can be simultaneously proven to be a part of a Merkle tree defined by
    3124                 :             :      * `root`, according to `proof` and `proofFlags` as described in {processMultiProof}.
    3125                 :             :      *
    3126                 :             :      * This version handles multiproofs in calldata with the default hashing function.
    3127                 :             :      *
    3128                 :             :      * CAUTION: Not all Merkle trees admit multiproofs. See {processMultiProof} for details.
    3129                 :             :      *
    3130                 :             :      * NOTE: Consider the case where `root == proof[0] && leaves.length == 0` as it will return `true`.
    3131                 :             :      * The `leaves` must be validated independently. See {processMultiProofCalldata}.
    3132                 :             :      */
    3133                 :           0 :     function multiProofVerifyCalldata(
    3134                 :             :         bytes32[] calldata proof,
    3135                 :             :         bool[] calldata proofFlags,
    3136                 :             :         bytes32 root,
    3137                 :             :         bytes32[] memory leaves
    3138                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (bool) {
    3139                 :           0 :         return processMultiProofCalldata(proof, proofFlags, leaves) == root;
    3140                 :             :     }
    3141                 :             : 
    3142                 :             :     /**
    3143                 :             :      * @dev Returns the root of a tree reconstructed from `leaves` and sibling nodes in `proof`. The reconstruction
    3144                 :             :      * proceeds by incrementally reconstructing all inner nodes by combining a leaf/inner node with either another
    3145                 :             :      * leaf/inner node or a proof sibling node, depending on whether each `proofFlags` item is true or false
    3146                 :             :      * respectively.
    3147                 :             :      *
    3148                 :             :      * This version handles multiproofs in calldata with the default hashing function.
    3149                 :             :      *
    3150                 :             :      * CAUTION: Not all Merkle trees admit multiproofs. To use multiproofs, it is sufficient to ensure that: 1) the tree
    3151                 :             :      * is complete (but not necessarily perfect), 2) the leaves to be proven are in the opposite order they are in the
    3152                 :             :      * tree (i.e., as seen from right to left starting at the deepest layer and continuing at the next layer).
    3153                 :             :      *
    3154                 :             :      * NOTE: The _empty set_ (i.e. the case where `proof.length == 1 && leaves.length == 0`) is considered a no-op,
    3155                 :             :      * and therefore a valid multiproof (i.e. it returns `proof[0]`). Consider disallowing this case if you're not
    3156                 :             :      * validating the leaves elsewhere.
    3157                 :             :      */
    3158                 :           0 :     function processMultiProofCalldata(
    3159                 :             :         bytes32[] calldata proof,
    3160                 :             :         bool[] calldata proofFlags,
    3161                 :             :         bytes32[] memory leaves
    3162                 :             :     ) internal pure returns (bytes32 merkleRoot) {
    3163                 :             :         // This function rebuilds the root hash by traversing the tree up from the leaves. The root is rebuilt by
    3164                 :             :         // consuming and producing values on a queue. The queue starts with the `leaves` array, then goes onto the
    3165                 :             :         // `hashes` array. At the end of the process, the last hash in the `hashes` array should contain the root of
    3166                 :             :         // the Merkle tree.
    3167                 :           0 :         uint256 leavesLen = leaves.length;
    3168                 :           0 :         uint256 proofFlagsLen = proofFlags.length;
    3169                 :             : 
    3170                 :             :         // Check proof validity.
    3171            [ # ]:           0 :         if (leavesLen + proof.length != proofFlagsLen + 1) {
    3172                 :           0 :             revert MerkleProofInvalidMultiproof();
    3173                 :             :         }
    3174                 :             : 
    3175                 :             :         // The xxxPos values are "pointers" to the next value to consume in each array. All accesses are done using
    3176                 :             :         // `xxx[xxxPos++]`, which return the current value and increment the pointer, thus mimicking a queue's "pop".
    3177                 :           0 :         bytes32[] memory hashes = new bytes32[](proofFlagsLen);
    3178                 :           0 :         uint256 leafPos = 0;
    3179                 :           0 :         uint256 hashPos = 0;
    3180                 :           0 :         uint256 proofPos = 0;
    3181                 :             :         // At each step, we compute the next hash using two values:
    3182                 :             :         // - a value from the "main queue". If not all leaves have been consumed, we get the next leaf, otherwise we
    3183                 :             :         //   get the next hash.
    3184                 :             :         // - depending on the flag, either another value from the "main queue" (merging branches) or an element from the
    3185                 :             :         //   `proof` array.
    3186                 :           0 :         for (uint256 i = 0; i < proofFlagsLen; i++) {
    3187                 :           0 :             bytes32 a = leafPos < leavesLen ? leaves[leafPos++] : hashes[hashPos++];
    3188                 :           0 :             bytes32 b = proofFlags[i]
    3189                 :             :                 ? (leafPos < leavesLen ? leaves[leafPos++] : hashes[hashPos++])
    3190                 :             :                 : proof[proofPos++];
    3191                 :           0 :             hashes[i] = Hashes.commutativeKeccak256(a, b);
    3192                 :             :         }
    3193                 :             : 
    3194         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (proofFlagsLen > 0) {
    3195            [ # ]:           0 :             if (proofPos != proof.length) {
    3196                 :           0 :                 revert MerkleProofInvalidMultiproof();
    3197                 :             :             }
    3198                 :             :             unchecked {
    3199                 :           0 :                 return hashes[proofFlagsLen - 1];
    3200                 :             :             }
    3201         [ #  # ]:           0 :         } else if (leavesLen > 0) {
    3202                 :           0 :             return leaves[0];
    3203                 :             :         } else {
    3204                 :           0 :             return proof[0];
    3205                 :             :         }
    3206                 :             :     }
    3207                 :             : 
    3208                 :             :     /**
    3209                 :             :      * @dev Returns true if the `leaves` can be simultaneously proven to be a part of a Merkle tree defined by
    3210                 :             :      * `root`, according to `proof` and `proofFlags` as described in {processMultiProof}.
    3211                 :             :      *
    3212                 :             :      * This version handles multiproofs in calldata with a custom hashing function.
    3213                 :             :      *
    3214                 :             :      * CAUTION: Not all Merkle trees admit multiproofs. See {processMultiProof} for details.
    3215                 :             :      *
    3216                 :             :      * NOTE: Consider the case where `root == proof[0] && leaves.length == 0` as it will return `true`.
    3217                 :             :      * The `leaves` must be validated independently. See {processMultiProofCalldata}.
    3218                 :             :      */
    3219                 :           0 :     function multiProofVerifyCalldata(
    3220                 :             :         bytes32[] calldata proof,
    3221                 :             :         bool[] calldata proofFlags,
    3222                 :             :         bytes32 root,
    3223                 :             :         bytes32[] memory leaves,
    3224                 :             :         function(bytes32, bytes32) view returns (bytes32) hasher
    3225                 :             :     ) internal view returns (bool) {
    3226                 :           0 :         return processMultiProofCalldata(proof, proofFlags, leaves, hasher) == root;
    3227                 :             :     }
    3228                 :             : 
    3229                 :             :     /**
    3230                 :             :      * @dev Returns the root of a tree reconstructed from `leaves` and sibling nodes in `proof`. The reconstruction
    3231                 :             :      * proceeds by incrementally reconstructing all inner nodes by combining a leaf/inner node with either another
    3232                 :             :      * leaf/inner node or a proof sibling node, depending on whether each `proofFlags` item is true or false
    3233                 :             :      * respectively.
    3234                 :             :      *
    3235                 :             :      * This version handles multiproofs in calldata with a custom hashing function.
    3236                 :             :      *
    3237                 :             :      * CAUTION: Not all Merkle trees admit multiproofs. To use multiproofs, it is sufficient to ensure that: 1) the tree
    3238                 :             :      * is complete (but not necessarily perfect), 2) the leaves to be proven are in the opposite order they are in the
    3239                 :             :      * tree (i.e., as seen from right to left starting at the deepest layer and continuing at the next layer).
    3240                 :             :      *
    3241                 :             :      * NOTE: The _empty set_ (i.e. the case where `proof.length == 1 && leaves.length == 0`) is considered a no-op,
    3242                 :             :      * and therefore a valid multiproof (i.e. it returns `proof[0]`). Consider disallowing this case if you're not
    3243                 :             :      * validating the leaves elsewhere.
    3244                 :             :      */
    3245                 :           0 :     function processMultiProofCalldata(
    3246                 :             :         bytes32[] calldata proof,
    3247                 :             :         bool[] calldata proofFlags,
    3248                 :             :         bytes32[] memory leaves,
    3249                 :             :         function(bytes32, bytes32) view returns (bytes32) hasher
    3250                 :             :     ) internal view returns (bytes32 merkleRoot) {
    3251                 :             :         // This function rebuilds the root hash by traversing the tree up from the leaves. The root is rebuilt by
    3252                 :             :         // consuming and producing values on a queue. The queue starts with the `leaves` array, then goes onto the
    3253                 :             :         // `hashes` array. At the end of the process, the last hash in the `hashes` array should contain the root of
    3254                 :             :         // the Merkle tree.
    3255                 :           0 :         uint256 leavesLen = leaves.length;
    3256                 :           0 :         uint256 proofFlagsLen = proofFlags.length;
    3257                 :             : 
    3258                 :             :         // Check proof validity.
    3259            [ # ]:           0 :         if (leavesLen + proof.length != proofFlagsLen + 1) {
    3260                 :           0 :             revert MerkleProofInvalidMultiproof();
    3261                 :             :         }
    3262                 :             : 
    3263                 :             :         // The xxxPos values are "pointers" to the next value to consume in each array. All accesses are done using
    3264                 :             :         // `xxx[xxxPos++]`, which return the current value and increment the pointer, thus mimicking a queue's "pop".
    3265                 :           0 :         bytes32[] memory hashes = new bytes32[](proofFlagsLen);
    3266                 :           0 :         uint256 leafPos = 0;
    3267                 :           0 :         uint256 hashPos = 0;
    3268                 :           0 :         uint256 proofPos = 0;
    3269                 :             :         // At each step, we compute the next hash using two values:
    3270                 :             :         // - a value from the "main queue". If not all leaves have been consumed, we get the next leaf, otherwise we
    3271                 :             :         //   get the next hash.
    3272                 :             :         // - depending on the flag, either another value from the "main queue" (merging branches) or an element from the
    3273                 :             :         //   `proof` array.
    3274                 :           0 :         for (uint256 i = 0; i < proofFlagsLen; i++) {
    3275                 :           0 :             bytes32 a = leafPos < leavesLen ? leaves[leafPos++] : hashes[hashPos++];
    3276                 :           0 :             bytes32 b = proofFlags[i]
    3277                 :             :                 ? (leafPos < leavesLen ? leaves[leafPos++] : hashes[hashPos++])
    3278                 :             :                 : proof[proofPos++];
    3279                 :           0 :             hashes[i] = hasher(a, b);
    3280                 :             :         }
    3281                 :             : 
    3282         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (proofFlagsLen > 0) {
    3283            [ # ]:           0 :             if (proofPos != proof.length) {
    3284                 :           0 :                 revert MerkleProofInvalidMultiproof();
    3285                 :             :             }
    3286                 :             :             unchecked {
    3287                 :           0 :                 return hashes[proofFlagsLen - 1];
    3288                 :             :             }
    3289         [ #  # ]:           0 :         } else if (leavesLen > 0) {
    3290                 :           0 :             return leaves[0];
    3291                 :             :         } else {
    3292                 :           0 :             return proof[0];
    3293                 :             :         }
    3294                 :             :     }
    3295                 :             : }
    3296                 :             : 
    3297                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/access/Ownable.sol
    3298                 :             : 
    3299                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.0.0) (access/Ownable.sol)
    3300                 :             : 
    3301                 :             : /**
    3302                 :             :  * @dev Contract module which provides a basic access control mechanism, where
    3303                 :             :  * there is an account (an owner) that can be granted exclusive access to
    3304                 :             :  * specific functions.
    3305                 :             :  *
    3306                 :             :  * The initial owner is set to the address provided by the deployer. This can
    3307                 :             :  * later be changed with {transferOwnership}.
    3308                 :             :  *
    3309                 :             :  * This module is used through inheritance. It will make available the modifier
    3310                 :             :  * `onlyOwner`, which can be applied to your functions to restrict their use to
    3311                 :             :  * the owner.
    3312                 :             :  */
    3313                 :             : abstract contract Ownable is Context {
    3314                 :             :     address private _owner;
    3315                 :             : 
    3316                 :             :     /**
    3317                 :             :      * @dev The caller account is not authorized to perform an operation.
    3318                 :             :      */
    3319                 :             :     error OwnableUnauthorizedAccount(address account);
    3320                 :             : 
    3321                 :             :     /**
    3322                 :             :      * @dev The owner is not a valid owner account. (eg. `address(0)`)
    3323                 :             :      */
    3324                 :             :     error OwnableInvalidOwner(address owner);
    3325                 :             : 
    3326                 :             :     event OwnershipTransferred(address indexed previousOwner, address indexed newOwner);
    3327                 :             : 
    3328                 :             :     /**
    3329                 :             :      * @dev Initializes the contract setting the address provided by the deployer as the initial owner.
    3330                 :             :      */
    3331                 :          58 :     constructor(address initialOwner) {
    3332            [ # ]:          58 :         if (initialOwner == address(0)) {
    3333                 :           0 :             revert OwnableInvalidOwner(address(0));
    3334                 :             :         }
    3335                 :          58 :         _transferOwnership(initialOwner);
    3336                 :             :     }
    3337                 :             : 
    3338                 :             :     /**
    3339                 :             :      * @dev Throws if called by any account other than the owner.
    3340                 :             :      */
    3341                 :          20 :     modifier onlyOwner() {
    3342                 :           0 :         _checkOwner();
    3343                 :             :         _;
    3344                 :             :     }
    3345                 :             : 
    3346                 :             :     /**
    3347                 :             :      * @dev Returns the address of the current owner.
    3348                 :             :      */
    3349                 :         192 :     function owner() public view virtual returns (address) {
    3350                 :         192 :         return _owner;
    3351                 :             :     }
    3352                 :             : 
    3353                 :             :     /**
    3354                 :             :      * @dev Throws if the sender is not the owner.
    3355                 :             :      */
    3356                 :         192 :     function _checkOwner() internal view virtual {
    3357            [ # ]:         192 :         if (owner() != _msgSender()) {
    3358                 :           0 :             revert OwnableUnauthorizedAccount(_msgSender());
    3359                 :             :         }
    3360                 :             :     }
    3361                 :             : 
    3362                 :             :     /**
    3363                 :             :      * @dev Leaves the contract without owner. It will not be possible to call
    3364                 :             :      * `onlyOwner` functions. Can only be called by the current owner.
    3365                 :             :      *
    3366                 :             :      * NOTE: Renouncing ownership will leave the contract without an owner,
    3367                 :             :      * thereby disabling any functionality that is only available to the owner.
    3368                 :             :      */
    3369                 :           0 :     function renounceOwnership() public virtual onlyOwner {
    3370                 :           0 :         _transferOwnership(address(0));
    3371                 :             :     }
    3372                 :             : 
    3373                 :             :     /**
    3374                 :             :      * @dev Transfers ownership of the contract to a new account (`newOwner`).
    3375                 :             :      * Can only be called by the current owner.
    3376                 :             :      */
    3377                 :           0 :     function transferOwnership(address newOwner) public virtual onlyOwner {
    3378            [ # ]:           0 :         if (newOwner == address(0)) {
    3379                 :           0 :             revert OwnableInvalidOwner(address(0));
    3380                 :             :         }
    3381                 :           0 :         _transferOwnership(newOwner);
    3382                 :             :     }
    3383                 :             : 
    3384                 :             :     /**
    3385                 :             :      * @dev Transfers ownership of the contract to a new account (`newOwner`).
    3386                 :             :      * Internal function without access restriction.
    3387                 :             :      */
    3388                 :          58 :     function _transferOwnership(address newOwner) internal virtual {
    3389                 :          58 :         address oldOwner = _owner;
    3390                 :          58 :         _owner = newOwner;
    3391                 :          58 :         emit OwnershipTransferred(oldOwner, newOwner);
    3392                 :             :     }
    3393                 :             : }
    3394                 :             : 
    3395                 :             : // node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/utils/ShortStrings.sol
    3396                 :             : 
    3397                 :             : // OpenZeppelin Contracts (last updated v5.1.0) (utils/ShortStrings.sol)
    3398                 :             : 
    3399                 :             : // | string  | 0xAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA   |
    3400                 :             : // | length  | 0x                                                              BB |
    3401                 :             : type ShortString is bytes32;
    3402                 :             : 
    3403                 :             : /**
    3404                 :             :  * @dev This library provides functions to convert short memory strings
    3405                 :             :  * into a `ShortString` type that can be used as an immutable variable.
    3406                 :             :  *
    3407                 :             :  * Strings of arbitrary length can be optimized using this library if
    3408                 :             :  * they are short enough (up to 31 bytes) by packing them with their
    3409                 :             :  * length (1 byte) in a single EVM word (32 bytes). Additionally, a
    3410                 :             :  * fallback mechanism can be used for every other case.
    3411                 :             :  *
    3412                 :             :  * Usage example:
    3413                 :             :  *
    3414                 :             :  * ```solidity
    3415                 :             :  * contract Named {
    3416                 :             :  *     using ShortStrings for *;
    3417                 :             :  *
    3418                 :             :  *     ShortString private immutable _name;
    3419                 :             :  *     string private _nameFallback;
    3420                 :             :  *
    3421                 :             :  *     constructor(string memory contractName) {
    3422                 :             :  *         _name = contractName.toShortStringWithFallback(_nameFallback);
    3423                 :             :  *     }
    3424                 :             :  *
    3425                 :             :  *     function name() external view returns (string memory) {
    3426                 :             :  *         return _name.toStringWithFallback(_nameFallback);
